{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|2010 JL|88}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | name = {{mp|2010 JL|88}} | background = #FFC2E0 | image = Orbit of 2010 JL88.gif | image_size = 265 | caption = Orbit of {{mp|2010 JL|88}} | discovery_ref =   | discoverer = | discovered = 15 May 2010 | discovery_site = [[Siding Spring Survey]]
{{small|(unaccredited)}} | mpc_name = {{mp|2010 JL|88}} | mp_category = [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo]]{{·}}[[Near-Earth object|NEO]]  | alt_names = | orbit_ref =   | epoch = 13 January 2016 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2457400.5) | uncertainty = 7 | aphelion = 2.1391 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 0.70654 AU | semimajor = 1.4228 AU | eccentricity = 0.50343 | period = 1.70 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (619.91 [[Julian year (astronomy)|d]]) | inclination = 0.092387° | asc_node = 269.02° | mean_anomaly = 89.113[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.58073|sup=ms}} /day | arg_peri = 51.167° | moid = 0.000956 AU | dimensions = {{val|18.5|7.5}} [[Metre|m]] | rotation = 24.5 [[Second|s]] {{small|(0.0068295 [[Hour|h]])}} | albedo = 0.1 | single_temperature=186–323 K | spectral_type = | abs_magnitude = 26.8 }} '''{{mp|2010 JL|88}}''' is an unnumbered [[asteroid]], classified as a [[near-Earth object]] of the [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo group]], approximately 19 meters in diameter. It was first observed by the [[Siding Spring Survey]], Australia, on 15 May 2010. It is known to be the [[Fast rotator (asteroid)|fastest rotator]] with an unambiguous period solution, having an exceptionally rapid [[rotation period]] of less than 25 seconds. On May 17, 2010, it passed {{convert|0.00257|AU|km|abbr=on|lk=on}} from Earth. It is on the lower of the [[Sentry Risk Table]]. == Earth impact possibility == {{mp|2010 JL|88}} has an [[Earth]] [[minimum orbit intersection distance]] of 0.45 Lunar Distances{{cite web | url=http://comets-asteroids.findthedata.org/l/584513/2010-JL88 | title=Comets and Asteroids: (2010 JL88) | work=Find the Data | date=November 11, 2013 | accessdate=8 December 2013}} However, it only has a 1 in 1,449,000 (0.000069%) chance of impacting into Earth sometime after 2049. Even if it did impact, {{mp|2010 JL|88}} is so small that it would simply disintegrate in a manner similar to the [[Chelyabinsk meteor]].{{cite web | url=http://janus.astro.umd.edu/cgi-bin/astro/impact/ | title=Solar System Collisions | publisher=Astronomy Workshop | accessdate=8 December 2013 | author=Hamilton, Douglas}} == Rotation == The asteroid was found to have a rapid rotation by the [[Magdalena Ridge Observatory]]'s 2.4-meter telescope. It rotates at an extremely rapid rate of 24.5 seconds. {{mp|2010 JL|88}} is the second fastest natural rotating object discovered in the [[Solar System]], after [[2014 RC]], which has a period of 16 seconds but still an uncertain period solution. == See also == [[List of exceptional asteroids]] [[List of fast rotators (minor planets)]] == References == {{reflist |refs= {{cite web |type = 2010-05-17 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: 2010 JL88 |url = http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=3522159 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 20 September 2016}} {{cite web |title = 2010 JL88 |work = Minor Planet Center |url = http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=2010+JL88 |accessdate = 20 September 2016}} {{cite news |url = http://www.hohmanntransfer.com/mn/10/10138_0518.htm |title = The Tracking News |work = hohmanntransfer.com |date = May 18, 2010 |accessdate = 3 December 2013}} {{Cite journal |first1 = Eileen V. |last1 = Ryan |first2 = W. H. |last2 = Ryan |date = October 2010 |title = Rotation Rates of Very Small Near-Earth Asteroids |url = http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/bib_query?bibcode=2010DPS....42.6003R |journal = American Astronomical Society |volume = 42 |page = 1086 |bibcode = 2010DPS....42.6003R |access-date= 20 September 2016}} {{cite web | url = http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/risk/2010jl88.html | title = 2010 JL88 Impact Risk | publisher = [[National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] | work = Jet Propulsion Laboratory | date = August 8, 2013 | accessdate= 31 March 2016}} {{cite web | url=http://phl.upr.edu/projects/habitable-exoplanets-catalog/calculators | title=HEC: Exoplanets Calculator | publisher=University of Puerto Rico at Arecibo | work=Planetary Habitability Laboratory | accessdate=10 December 2014}} {{cite web|url=http://www.physics.sfasu.edu/astro/asteroids/sizemagnitude.html |title=Conversion of Absolute Magnitude to Diameter for Minor Planets |publisher=Dan Burton |work=Sephen F. Austin State University |accessdate=26 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081210190134/http://www.physics.sfasu.edu/astro/asteroids/sizemagnitude.html |archivedate=10 December 2008 |df= }} {{cite web | url=http://astronomy.activeboard.com/index.spark?aBID=58381&p=3&topicID=35926424&page=0 | title=Asteroid 2010 JL88 | date=May 17, 2010 | accessdate=3 December 2013 | author=Blobrana}} }} == External links == * [http://www.minorplanet.info/PHP/lcdbsummaryquery.php Asteroid Lightcurve Database (LCDB)], query form ([http://www.minorplanet.info/lightcurvedatabase.html info]) * {{NeoDys|2010JL88}} * {{JPL small body}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2010 JL88}} [[Category:Apollo asteroids|#]] [[Category:Unnumbered minor planets]] [[Category:Near-Earth objects in 2010|20100517]] [[Category:Earth-crosser asteroids]] [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 2010|20100515]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|2012 YQ|1}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | background = #FFC2E0 | name = {{mp|2012 YQ|1}} | image = Asteroids-PHA-and-NEA-Orbits.jpg | image_size = 250 | caption = [[Orbits]] of a typical PHA ([[Potentially Hazardous Asteroid]]) and NEA ([[Near-Earth Asteroid]]). | discovery_ref = | discoverer = A. Oreshko
[[Timur Valer'evič Krjačko|T. Kryachko]] | discovery_site = [[IAU code#G32|Elena Remote Obs.]] | discovered = 19 December 2012
{{small|(first observed only)}} | mpc_name = {{mp|2012 YQ|1}} | alt_names = | mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[Apollo asteroids|Apollo]]{{·}}[[Potentially hazardous asteroid|PHA]]  | orbit_ref = | epoch = 13 January 2016 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2457400.5) | uncertainty = 6 | aphelion = {{Convert|3.11880|AU|Gm|abbr=on|lk=on}} | perihelion = {{Convert|0.86916|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} | semimajor = {{Convert|1.99398|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} | eccentricity = 0.56411 | period = 2.82 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (1028.4 [[Julian year (astronomy)|d]]) | inclination = 5.15193° | asc_node = 120.16813° | mean_anomaly = 12.74578[[Degree (angle)|°]] | arg_peri = 42.09537° | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.350044|sup=ms}} /day | moid = {{Convert|0.00774939|AU|km|abbr=on}} | mean_diameter = ~{{convert|220|m|ft|abbr=on}} | spectral_type = | abs_magnitude = {{val|21.1}}{{·}}20.9 }} '''{{mp|2012 YQ|1}}''' is a sub-kilometer [[asteroid]], classified as a [[near-Earth object]] and a [[potentially hazardous asteroid]] of the [[Apollo asteroids|Apollo group]], approximately 200 meters in diameter. It was first observed on 19 December 2012, by astronomers Andrey Oreshko and [[Timur Valer'evič Krjačko|Timur Kryachko]] at the Elena Remote Observatory ({{small|[[IAU code#G32|G32]]}}) located in the Chilean Atacama desert. == Description == With a 4-day observation arc, the asteroid had a 1 in 3 million chance of impacting in 2106. With a 10-day observation arc, the asteroid had a 1 in 10 million chance of impacting in 2106. On 5 January 2013, the asteroid passed {{convert|0.10|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} from Earth. It was removed from the [[Sentry (monitoring system)|Sentry Risk Table]] on 8 January 2013. It has an observation arc of 32 days and an orbital [[Uncertainty Parameter U|uncertainty]] of 7. Since the asteroid has a poorly known orbit, the [[cone of uncertainty]] quickly multiplies as a result of [[Perturbation (astronomy)|perturbations]] by the inner planets and prevents precise/reliable ephemeris data. Eliminating an entry on the Sentry Risk Table is a negative prediction; a prediction of where it will NOT be. === In the popular press === In 2013, an article, originally posted on [[The Voice of Russia]]{{cite journal | journal =The Voice of Russia | date=5 February 2013 | author=Yulia Zamanskaya | title= We have 93 years left till the next End of the World: killer asteroid to hit Earth in 2106 | url=http://sputniknews.com/voiceofrussia/2013_02_05/We-have-93-years-left-till-the-next-End-of-the-World-killer-asteroid-to-hit-Earth-in-2106/}} had a poorly researched headline stating "We have 93 years left till the next End of the World". This story was reposted on Space Daily, but then astronomer [[Phil Plait]] clarified that it was "a fascinating mix of fact and error. A lot of what it says is accurate, but the most important claim—that an asteroid will impact Earth in 2106—is simply wrong."{{cite journal | journal=Slate| title=No, An Asteroid Is NOT Going to Hit Earth in 2106 | author= Phil Plait | date = 13 Feb 2013 | url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/bad_astronomy/2013/02/13/asteroid_impact_2106_reports_of_a_space_rock_hitting_us_are_exaggerated.html}} [[File:Orbit-2012-YQ1-Today-20130206-20130206-test4433.gif|thumb|left|450px|Orbit (blue) of asteroid 2012 YQ1 for 6 February 2013]] {{Clear|left}} ==See also== * [[Torino Scale]] * [[Palermo scale]] |accessdate=2013-02-06}} ([http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/cgi-bin/ip?3.3e-07 3.3e-07] = 1 in 3,030,000 chance) {{cite web |date=2012-12-30 |title=Observations of small Solar-System bodies {{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|2015 TB|145}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | background = #FFC2E0 | name = {{mp|2015 TB|145}} | image = 2015 TB145 orbit 2015.png|thumb|2015 TB145 flyby in October 2015 | discovery_ref = | discoverer = [[Pan-STARRS]] | discovered = 10 October 2015 | mpc_name = {{mp|2015 TB|145}} | mp_category = [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo]], [[Near-Earth object|NEO]], [[Potentially hazardous object|PHA]],
[[Mercury-crosser asteroid]],
[[Venus-crosser asteroid]],
[[Mars-crosser asteroid]] | orbit_ref = | epoch = 13 January 2016 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2457400.5) | tisserand = 2.964 | uncertainty = 2 | observation_arc = 22 days | aphelion = {{Convert|3.9076|AU|Gm|abbr=on|lk=on}} (Q) | perihelion = {{Convert|0.29345|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} (q) | semimajor = {{Convert|2.1005|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} (a) | eccentricity = 0.86030 (e) | period = 3.04 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (1112.0 [[Julian year (astronomy)|d]]) | inclination = 39.6863° (i) | asc_node = 37.7318° (Ω) | mean_anomaly = 10.4818[[Degree (angle)|°]] (M) | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.32375|sup=ms}} / day (n) | arg_peri = 121.731° (ω) | dimensions = {{val|650|30|u=m}} ({{val|2130|100|u=ft}})
{{val|600|u=m}} | rotation = 5 hours,[http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4760 Halloween Skies to Include Dead Comet Flyby]. NASA-JPL press release. October 30, 2015 {{Convert|2.938|h|d|abbr=on|lk=on}} | abs_magnitude = 20.0 | albedo = 0.06 | moid = {{Convert|0.00155156|AU|km|abbr=on}} | jupiter_moid = {{Convert|2.41379|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} }} '''{{mp|2015 TB|145}}''' is a sub-kilometer [[asteroid]], classified as [[near-Earth object]] and [[potentially hazardous asteroid]] of the [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo group]], approximately {{convert|650|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=off|sp=us}} in diameter. It safely passed 1.27 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distance]]s from [[Earth]] on 31 October 2015 at 17:01 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]., and will pass by Earth again in November 2018. The asteroid has not been observed since 2015. == Discovery== [[File:2015 TB145 discovery.gif|thumb|left|Discovery image of 2015 TB145 from the Pan-STARRS1 telescope, operated by the Institute for Astronomy at the University of Hawaii]] The asteroid was first observed on 10 October 2015 by [[Pan-STARRS]] at an apparent magnitude of 20 using a {{convert|1.8|m|in|adj=on|sp=us}} [[Ritchey–Chrétien telescope]].{{refn|For comparison, around 6 October 2012 the asteroid peaked at about apparent magnitude 20.9, but had a [[solar elongation]] of only about 75 degrees while 0.4[[astronomical unit|AU]] from Earth.|name=ND2012|group=lower-alpha}} The asteroid was not discovered sooner because it spends most of its time beyond the orbit of [[Mars]], has a large orbital inclination, and spends most of its time well below the [[plane of the ecliptic]]. The asteroid last passed within {{convert|0.064|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} of Earth on 29 October 1923 and will not pass that close again until 1 November 2088. The media has nicknamed the asteroid the "Great Pumpkin"{{cite news |url= http://time.com/4094227/nasa-great-pumpkin-asteroid/ |title= NASA Says ‘Great Pumpkin’ Asteroid Will Fly by on Halloween |author= Sarah Begley |date= 30 October 2015 |publisher= [[TIME Magazine]]}} after the animated [[Halloween]] television special ''[[It's the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown]]'', "Spooky",{{cite news| url= http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2015/10/151023-astronomy-asteroid-encounter-Earth-stargazing-nasa/ | title= Asteroid Called ‘Spooky’ Will Buzz Earth on Halloween |author=Andrew Fazekas |date=23 October 2015 |publisher=[[National Geographic Society]]}}{{cite news |url= https://www.rt.com/news/320209-spooky-asteroid-earth-halloween/ |title= ‘Spooky’ asteroid to fly by Earth on Halloween |author=RT |date=31 October 2015 |publisher=RT (Russia Today)}} the “Halloween Asteroid”,{{cite news |url= http://www.ibtimes.com/halloween-asteroid-2015-tb145-hurtling-toward-earth-80000-mph-doomsday-threat-2149173 |title= Halloween Asteroid 2015 TB145 Hurtling Toward Earth At 80,000 MPH: Doomsday Threat? |author= Charles Poladian |date= 20 October 2015 |publisher= [[International Business Times]]}}{{cite news |url= https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2015/10/its-dead/413518/ |title= A Halloween Comet| author=Morina Koren |date=31 October 2015 |publisher=[[The Atlantic]]}}{{cite news |url= http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Operations/Space_Situational_Awareness/Halloween_asteroid_gives_us_a_miss_confirms_ESA |title= Halloween Asteroid Gives us a Miss, Confirms ESA |author=ESA |date=28 October 2015 |publisher=[[European Space Agency]]}} and the “Skull Asteroid”{{cite news| url= https://nypost.com/2015/10/31/spooky-skull-asteroid-whizzes-past-earth-on-halloween/ |title= Spooky ‘skull asteroid’ whizzes past Earth on Halloween |author=Nick Divito |date=31 October 2015 |publisher=[[New York Post]]}} due to its [[human skull]]-like appearance following [[radio frequency]] images taken at [[Arecibo Observatory]] and closest approach coincidentally occurring on Halloween day. ==2015 flyby== [[File:2015 TB145 flyby.png|left|thumb|2015 TB145 passed 1.27 LD from the earth, and 0.75 LD from the moon.]] On 31 October 2015 the asteroid passed {{convert|0.00191|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} from the [[Moon]] and then passed {{convert|0.00325|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}} from Earth. The last approach this close by an object with [[Absolute magnitude#Solar System bodies (H)|absolute magnitude]] brighter than 20 was {{mpl|2004 XP|14}} on 3 July 2006 at 1.1 lunar distances. The next object this large known to pass this close to Earth is {{mpl|(137108) 1999 AN|10}} that will pass about 1 lunar distance from Earth on 7 August 2027. It is estimated that there are about 2400 near-Earth asteroids 300–500 meters in diameter, of which about 1100 have been discovered. During closest approach to Earth the asteroid reached about [[apparent magnitude]] 10, which is much too faint to be seen by the naked eye. Even at peak brightness, the asteroid was a challenging target for [[amateur astronomer]]s with small telescopes, best seen in the [[Northern hemisphere]]. The glare from an 80% [[Lunar phase|waning gibbous]] Moon also hindered observations. At 11:00 UT the asteroid was in the constellation of [[Taurus (constellation)|Taurus]] about 9 degrees from the Moon and moving at a rate of 3.4 degrees per hour. At the time of closest approach of 17:00 UT the asteroid was in the constellation of [[Ursa Major]] about 56 degrees from the Moon and moving at a rate of 14.7 degrees per hour. After closest approach it quickly became too faint and too close to the Sun in the sky to be seen. [[File:2015 TB145 skypath.png|550px]] {{Large near earth asteroid flybys 2LD}} ==2018 flyby== On 11 November 2018 the flyby about {{convert|0.27|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} from Earth. It will only brighten to magnitude 19.{{cite web|url=https://www.universetoday.com/140108/the-death-comet-will-pass-by-earth-just-after-halloween/|title=The “Death Comet” Will Pass By Earth Just After Halloween|date=1 October 2018|author=Williams, Matt| publisher=Universe Today|access-date=13 October 2018}} After it had been unobservable for almost three years, {{mp|2015 TB|145}} has been recovered on 7 October 2018 by L. Buzzi at Schiaparelli Observatory, at apparent magnitude 21.{{cite web|url=https://minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K18/K18TD0.html|title=MPEC 2018-T130: 2015 TB145|publisher=Minor Planet Center|date=10 October 2018|access-date=13 October 2018}} ==Observations== === Radar imagery=== The close approach was studied with [[Radar astronomy|radar]] using [[Goldstone Deep Space Communications Complex|Goldstone]], the [[Green Bank Telescope]], and the [[Arecibo Observatory]]. It was one of the best radar targets of the year with a resolution as high as {{convert|2|m|ft|sigfig=1|sp=us}} per pixel. Bistatic radar images created with the Green Bank Telescope had a resolution of {{convert|4|m|ft|sigfig=2|sp=us}} per pixel. Arecibo images had a resolution of {{convert|7.5|m|ft|sigfig=2|sp=us}} per pixel. {| class=wikitable !October 30 !October 31
12:55 - 13:08 UTC !November 1 |- |[[File:PIA20041-Asteroid-2015TB145-Animation-20151030.gif|150px|]] |[[File:Halloween asteroid rotation animation.gif|150px]] |[[File:2015TB145 November 1.webm|150px]] |} == Possible cometary origin == The high [[orbital inclination]] and eccentricity suggest {{mp|2015 TB|145}} may be an [[extinct comet]] that has shed its volatiles after numerous passes around the Sun.{{cite news |last=Agle |first=D. C. |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4745 |title=NASA Spots the 'Great Pumpkin': Halloween Asteroid a Treat for Radar Astronomers |work=NASA News |date=21 October 2015 |accessdate=2015-10-26 }} Orbital calculations by [[Peter Jenniskens|Petrus Jenniskens]] and Jérémie Vaubaillon showed that it was not expected to produce associated meteors in 2015. Any meteoroids were expected to pass more than {{convert|0.0007|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}} from Earth's orbit. If meteoroids related to this asteroid were to cross Earth's path, the [[Radiant (meteor shower)|radiant]] is expected to be near Northern [[Eridanus (constellation)|Eridanus]]. Cameras for Allsky Meteor Surveillance (CAMS) did not detect any activity in the presumed area of the sky during 2013 and 2014. The object has a low [[Albedo#Astronomical albedo|albedo]] of 0.06, which is only slightly more than a typical comet that has an albedo of 0.03-0.05. {{clear}} == Notes == {{Notelist}} == References == {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web |title=MPEC 2015-T86 : 2015 TB145 |publisher=[[IAU Minor Planet Center]] |date=2015-10-13 |url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K15/K15T86.html |accessdate=2015-10-14}} (K15TE5B) {{cite web |type=last observation: 2015-10-27; [[Observation arc|arc]]: 17 days |title=JPL Small-Body Database Browser: (2015 TB145) |url=https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2015TB145;cad=1 |publisher=[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate=4 April 2016}} {{cite journal | url=https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2017/02/aa29584-16.pdf | arxiv=1610.08267| title=Large Halloween asteroid at lunar distance | author1=Müller, T. G. | author2=Marciniak, A. | author3=Butkiewicz-Bąk, M. | author4=Duffard, R. | author5=Oszkiewicz, D. | author6=Käufl, H. U. | author7=Szakáts, R. | author8=Santana-Ros, T. | author9=Kiss, C. | author10=Santos-Sanz, P. | journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics | volume=598 | pages=A63 | doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201629584 | date=February 2017 | access-date=13 October 2018}} {{cite web |type=last observation: 2015-10-27; [[Observation arc|arc]]: 17 days |title=JPL Close-Approach Data: (2015 TB145) |url=https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2015TB145;cad=1#cad |accessdate=2015-10-22}} {{cite web |title = Asteroid Size Estimator |publisher = CNEOS NASA/JPL |url = https://cneos.jpl.nasa.gov/tools/ast_size_est.html |accessdate = 16 February 2018}} {{cite web |title=2015TB145 Ephemerides for 15 October 2015 through 31 October 2015 |publisher=[[NEODyS]] (Near Earth Objects – Dynamic Site) |url=http://newton.dm.unipi.it/neodys/index.php?pc=1.1.3.1&n=2015TB145&oc=500&y0=2015&m0=10&d0=15&h0=0&mi0=0&y1=2015&m1=11&d1=1&h1=0&mi1=0&ti=1.0&tiu=hours |accessdate=2015-10-14}} {{cite web |title=2015 TB145 Orbit |publisher=IAU Minor Planet Center |url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=2015+TB145 |accessdate=2016-01-24}} {{cite web |date=24 October 2015 |title=Goldstone Radar Observations Planning: 2009 FD and 2015 TB145 |publisher=NASA/JPL Asteroid Radar Research |author=Dr. [http://science.jpl.nasa.gov/people/Benner/ Lance A. M. Benner] |url=http://echo.jpl.nasa.gov/asteroids/2009FD/2009FD_planning.html |accessdate=2015-10-24}} {{cite web |title=Close-in Asteroid Offers Halloween Treat |publisher=[[Sky & Telescope]] |author=Kelly Beatty |date=2015-10-22 |url=http://www.skyandtelescope.com/astronomy-news/observing-news/close-in-asteroid-halloween-treat-102220155/ |accessdate=2015-10-26}} {{cite web |date=2011-09-29 |title=WISE Revises Numbers of Asteroids Near Earth |publisher=NASA/JPL |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/WISE/multimedia/gallery/neowise/pia14734.html |accessdate=2015-10-29}} [http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/WISE/news/wise20110929.html (NASA Space Telescope Finds Fewer Asteroids Near Earth)] {{cite web |title=2015TB145 Ephemerides for October 2012 |publisher=[[NEODyS]] (Near Earth Objects – Dynamic Site) |url=http://newton.dm.unipi.it/neodys/index.php?pc=1.1.3.1&n=2015TB145&oc=500&y0=2012&m0=10&d0=1&h0=0&mi0=0&y1=2012&m1=10&d1=15&h1=17&mi1=36&ti=1.0&tiu=days |accessdate=2015-10-24}} {{cite web |title = Possible October 31 Meteors From Minor Planet 2015 TB_145 |publisher = [[SETI Institute]] |date = 2015-10-26 |url = http://www.seti.org/seti-institute/news/possible-october-31-meteors-minor-planet-2015-tb145 |accessdate = 2015-10-26 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151028022252/http://www.seti.org/seti-institute/news/possible-october-31-meteors-minor-planet-2015-tb145 |archive-date = 28 October 2015 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }} [http://www.cbat.eps.harvard.edu/iau/cbet/004100/CBET004154.txt (CBET 4154)] {{cite web |date=2015-11-03 |title=PIA20043: Halloween Asteroid Rotation |publisher=NASA/JPL-Caltech/GSSR/NRAO/GB |url=http://photojournal.jpl.nasa.gov/catalog/PIA20043 |accessdate=2015-11-04}} }} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160112162246/http://www.itelescope.net/sky-alerts/2015/10/15/alert-bright-neo-2015-tb145-on-29-31-october-2015.html ALERT! Bright NEO 2015 TB145 on 29-31 October, 2015] – Ian Musgrave (itelescope) * [https://www.webcitation.org/6cHLsxfgA?url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2015TB145;cad=1 WebCite archive of JPL solution #2 from 2015-Oct-14] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RQoMAWTAxY4 Halloween Asteroid is a Radar Science Treat] (NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory on YouTube) * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-zJ6WQW-LXA Halloween Asteroid 2015 TB145 Flyby] Jerry Hilburn, 10/31/2015 12:12-12:24AM, Catfish Observatory, Teirra Del Sol, Canon 5D and an Orion ED 80 Refractor on an AVX Celestron Mount * {{JPL small body|id=3729835}} {{use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{2015 in space}} {{Planetary defense}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2015 TB145}} [[Category:Apollo asteroids|#]] [[Category:Unnumbered minor planets]] [[Category:Extinct comets|#]] [[Category:Venus-crosser asteroids]] [[Category:Mercury-crossing asteroids]] [[Category:Potentially hazardous asteroids|#]] [[Category:Near-Earth objects in 2015|20151031]] [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 2015|20151010]]

revision.comment: Alter: title. Add: pmid, pages, issue, volume, class, eprint. Removed accessdate with no specified URL. Removed parameters. Formatted [[WP:ENDASH|dashes]]. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[User:Headbomb|Headbomb]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox astronomical event |name = AT2018cow |image = Possible AT2018cow 244.000927647 +22.2680094118 20180624.png |image_size = 250px |caption = Location of AT2018cow |event_type = Astronomical explosion |start_time = {{start-date|df=yes|16 June 2018, 10:35:02}} [[UTC]]<ref name="AT-20180617" /> |duration = |detected_by = [[Asteroid Terrestrial-impact Last Alert System|ATLAS-HKO]]<ref name="AT-20180617" /> |constellation = [[Hercules (constellation)|Hercules]] |ra = {{RA|16|16|00.2242}}<ref name="AT-20180731" /><!--- Needs to be updated on Wikidata? - per [[User:Drbogdan]], 1 August 2018, 09:20 am/et/usa ---> {{RA|16|16|00.22}}<ref name="AT-20180617" /> (244.000927647)<ref name="TNS-20180622" /> |dec = {{DEC|+22|16|04.890}}<ref name="AT-20180731" /><!--- Needs to be updated on Wikidata? - per [[User:Drbogdan]], 1 August 2018, 09:20 am/et/usa ---> {{DEC|+22|16|04.83}}<ref name="AT-20180617" /> (+22.2680094118)<ref name="TNS-20180622" /> |epoch = [[J2000.0]] |distance = {{convert|60|Mpc|Mly|abbr=on|order=flip|lk=on}}<ref name="AT-20180617" /> |redshift = 0.014145,<ref name="AT-20180617" /> 0.0136<ref name="AT-20180710" /> (0.01406/parent galaxy)<ref name="AT-20180710" /><!--- Needs to be updated on Wikidata? - per [[User:Drbogdan]], 10 July 2018, 07:45 am/et/usa ---> |host = |progenitor = |progenitor_type = |b-v = |notes = |peak = |energy = |website = {{URL|http://atlas.fallingstar.com/}} }} {{Sky |16|16|00.2242 |+|22|16|04.890 |200000000}}<!---<ref name=""AT-20180731" />---><!--- Needs to be updated on Wikidata? - per [[User:Drbogdan]], 1 August 2018, 09:20 am/et/usa ---> '''AT2018cow''' ([[Asteroid Terrestrial-impact Last Alert System|ATLAS]] name: ATLAS18qqn; also known as Supernova 2018cow, SN 2018cow, and "The Cow"<!--- <ref name="NS-20180621" /> => https://www.newscientist.com/article/2172351-weve-just-seen-a-huge-space-explosion-and-dont-know-what-it-is/ --->) was a [[Superluminous supernova|very powerful astronomical explosion]], 10 – 100 times brighter than a normal supernova, spatially coincident with galaxy {{nowrap|CGCG 137-068}}, approximately {{convert|60|e6pc|e6ly|abbr=unit|order=flip|lk=on}} distant in the [[Hercules (constellation)|Hercules constellation]]. It was first detected on 16 June 2018 by the [[Asteroid Terrestrial-impact Last Alert System|ATLAS-HKO]] telescope, and had generated significant interest among astronomers throughout the world. Later, on 10 July 2018, and after AT2018cow had significantly faded, astronomers, based on followup studies with the [[Nordic Optical Telescope]] (NOT), formally described AT2018cow as SN 2018cow, a [[Supernova#Type I|type Ib supernova]], showing an "unprecedented spectrum for a supernova of this class"; although others, mostly at first but also more recently, have referred to it as a [[Supernova#Type I|type Ic-BL supernova]]. An explanation to help better understand the unique features of AT2018cow has been presented.
On 2 November 2018, two independent teams of astronomers both concluded that the AT2018cow event was "either a newly formed [[black hole]] in the process of accreting matter, or the frenetic rotation of a [[neutron star]]."<ref name="NAT-20181102" /><ref name="ARX-20181025"/><ref name="ARX-20181028" /><ref name="ARX-20180812" />
==History== AT2018cow ([[Asteroid Terrestrial-impact Last Alert System|ATLAS]] name: ATLAS18qqn; also known as Supernova 2018cow, SN 2018cow, and "The Cow"<ref name="NAT-20181102" /><ref name="NS-20180621" />) was first detected on 16 June 2018 at 10:35:02 UTC by the [[Asteroid Terrestrial-impact Last Alert System|ATLAS-HKO]] telescope, a twin {{convert|0.5|m|in|abbr=on}} system, at the [[Haleakala Observatory]] in [[Hawaii]].<ref name="AT-20180617" /><ref name="NS-2018">{{cite web |author=Mandke, Mandar et al. |title=AT 2018 COW- the mysterious Supernova |url=http://www.natskies.com/2018/07/21/at-2018-cow-the-mysterious-supernova/ |date=21 July 2018 |work=NatSkies.com |accessdate=4 September 2018 }}</ref><ref name="ARX-20180830">{{Cite journal |arxiv=1807.05965|last1=Prentice|first1=S. J.|title=The Cow: Discovery of a luminous, hot and rapidly evolving transient|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=865|pages=L3|last2=Maguire|first2=K.|last3=Smartt|first3=S. J.|last4=Magee|first4=M. R.|last5=Schady|first5=P.|last6=Sim|first6=S.|last7=Chen|first7=T. -W.|last8=Clark|first8=P.|last9=Colin|first9=C.|last10=Fulton|first10=M.|last11=McBrien|first11=O.|last12=O'Neill|first12=D.|last13=Smith|first13=K. W.|last14=Ashall|first14=C.|last15=Chambers|first15=K. C.|last16=Denneau|first16=L.|last17=Flewelling|first17=H. A.|last18=Heinze|first18=A.|last19=Holoien|first19=T. W. -S.|last20=Huber|first20=M. E.|last21=Kochanek|first21=C. S.|last22=Mazzali|first22=P. A.|last23=Prieto|first23=J. L.|last24=Rest|first24=A.|last25=Shappee|first25=B. J.|last26=Stalder|first26=B.|last27=Stanek|first27=K. Z.|last28=Stritzinger|first28=M. D.|last29=Thompson|first29=T. A.|last30=Tonry|first30=J. L.|year=2018|doi=10.3847/2041-8213/aadd90}}</ref> It was a powerful astronomical explosion (discovery magnitude 14.739; [[redshift]] 0.014145,<ref name="AT-20180617" /> 0.0136<ref name="AT-20180710" />), 10 – 100 times brighter than a normal supernova,<ref name="ES-20180628">{{cite web |last=Anderson |first=Paul Scott |title=Astronomers see mystery explosion 200 million light-years away - Supernovae, or exploding stars, are relatively common. But now astronomers have observed a baffling new type of cosmic explosion, believed to be some 10 to 100 times brighter than an ordinary supernova. |url=http://earthsky.org/space/mystery-explosion-at2018cow-nicknamed-the-cow |date=28 June 2018 |work=[[Earth & Sky]] |accessdate=28 June 2018 }}</ref><ref name="TECH-20180626">{{cite web |author=Staff |title=Scientists Confused: A Huge Explosion Has Been Observed In Space |url=https://tech2.org/lithuania/scientists-confused-a-huge-explosion-has-been-observed-in-space/ |date=26 June 2018 |work=Tech2.org |accessdate=26 June 2018 }}</ref><ref name="WP-20180625" /><ref name="AT-20180625" /> spatially coincident with galaxy {{nowrap|CGCG 137-068}}, approximately {{convert|60|e6pc|e6ly|abbr=unit|order=flip|lk=on}} distant in the [[Hercules (constellation)|Hercules constellation]]. [[File:AT2018cow-context 244.000927647 +22.2680094118 20180627.jpg|thumb|left|150px|<center>AT2018cow - context</center>]] By 22 June 2018, this [[transient astronomical event]] had generated significant interest among astronomers throughout the world.<ref name="AT-20180622main">{{cite web |url=http://astronomerstelegram.org/ |title=Telegram Index |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] |date=22 June 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180622224952/http://astronomerstelegram.org/ |archivedate=22 June 2018 |accessdate=22 June 2018 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> At least 24 major telescopes were observing the event, the largest number, to date, of concurrent observations (over 35 posted on 27 June 2018)<ref name="AT-20180627main">{{cite web |url=http://astronomerstelegram.org/ |title=Telegram Index |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] |date=27 June 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180627163305/http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/|archivedate=27 June 2018 |accessdate=27 June 2018 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> of any astronomical event ever reported on ''[[The Astronomer's Telegram]]''.<ref name="WP-20180625" /><ref name="MU-20180624">{{cite news |url=http://mysteriousuniverse.org/2018/06/massive-explosion-of-unknown-origin-rips-through-neighboring-galaxy-at-incredible-speed/ |title=Massive Explosion of Unknown Origin Rips Through Neighboring Galaxy at 'Incredible Speed' |work=Mysterious Universe |first=Sequoyah |last=Kennedy |date=24 June 2018 |accessdate=25 June 2018}}</ref> The event had been tentatively identified as a supernova and given the designation Supernova 2018cow and classification [[Supernova#Type I|SN Ic-BL]].<ref name="TNS-20180622">{{cite web |url=https://wis-tns.weizmann.ac.il/object/2018cow |title=SN 2018cow |work=Transient Name Server |publisher=[[International Astronomical Union]] |date=22 June 2018 |accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="RA-20180622a">{{cite web |url=http://www.rochesterastronomy.org/supernova.html#2018cow |title=Latest SuperNovae |publisher=Astronomy Section, Rochester Academy of Sciences |last=Bishop |first=David |date=22 June 2018 |accessdate=22 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="RA-20180622b">{{cite web |url=http://www.rochesterastronomy.org/sn2018/sn2018cow.html |title=Supernovae 2018cow in CGCG 137-068 |publisher=Astronomy Section, Rochester Academy of Sciences |last=Bishop |first=David |date=22 June 2018 |accessdate=22 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="CS-20180624">{{cite web |url=https://www.calsky.com/observer/csrender.cgi?number=11&tdt=2458295.65490048&ra=16h16m00.220s&de=+22d16m04.83s&fovarcmin=15&coorEphem=TopoEquAstro2000 |title=The Calculated Sky - AT2018cow |publisher=Calsky.com |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180625130322/https://www.calsky.com/observer/csrender.cgi?number=11&tdt=2458295.65490048&ra=16h16m00.220s&de=+22d16m04.83s&fovarcmin=15&coorEphem=TopoEquAstro2000 |archivedate=25 June 2018 |access-date=25 June 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 25 June 2018, astronomers, using the {{convert|2.0|m|in|abbr=on}} [[Liverpool Telescope]] and the {{convert|1.5|m|in|abbr=on}} telescope at [[Palomar Observatory]], noted on ''[[The Astronomer's Telegram]]'': "AT2018cow has faded every night since our first observations ({{interp|19 June 2018, reference|orig=(ATEL#11732)}}). ... {{interp|Our reported|orig=These}} observations suggest that although a link to Ic-BL SNe and GRBs remains credible given the smooth [[Astronomical spectroscopy|spectra]] and luminous [[Radio astronomy|radio]] and [[X-ray astronomy|X-ray]] counterpart ({{interp|references|orig=ATEL#11737, #11749, #11773, #11774, #11775}}), AT2018cow is distinct in other ways and its true identity remains unclear. Observations are continuing."<ref name="WP-20180625" /><ref name="AT-20180625">{{cite journal |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11776 |title=AT2018cow: Continued optical fading and weakening of spectral features |journal=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] |first1=D. A. |last1=Perley |first2=N. |last2=Blagorodnova |first3=J. D. |last3=Neill |first4=R. |last4=Walters |display-authors=1 |issue=11776 |date=25 June 2018 |accessdate=25 June 2018}}</ref> On 29 June 2018, astronomers, using {{convert|0.6|m|in|abbr=on}} telescopes at the [[Beijing Astronomical Observatory]],<ref name="AT-20180629">{{cite web |author=Li, H. et al. |title=SVOM/GWAC-F60 and GRANDMA optical follow-up of AT2018cow/ATLAS18qqn |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11796 |date=29 June 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] (11796) |accessdate=30 June 2018 }}</ref> and on 30 June 2018, using the [[Neil Gehrels Swift Observatory#X-ray Telescope (XRT)|Swift/XRT telescope]],<ref name="AT-20180630">{{cite web |last1=Sandoval |first1=L.E. Rivera |last2=Maccarone |first2=T. |title= Increase in the X-ray flux of AT2018cow |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11801 |date=30 June 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] (11801)|accessdate=30 June 2018 }}</ref> reported further support for the fading of AT2018cow.
On 2 July 2018, astronomers, using the [[Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope|Fermi Large Area Telescope]] (LAT), reported that there were no significant >100 MeV [[Gamma-ray astronomy|gamma-ray emissions]] between 19–26 June 2018.<ref name="AT-20180702">{{cite web |last1=Kocevski |first1=D. |last2=Cheung |first2=C.C. |title=Fermi-LAT Search for Gamma-ray Emission from AT2018cow |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11808 |date=2 July 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] (11808)|accessdate=2 July 2018 }}</ref> Further, on 3 July 2018, astronomers reported, using the [[Astrosat#Payloads|Cadmium Zinc Telluride Imager]] (CZTI) detector aboard the [[Astrosat|AstroSat space observatory]], no [[X-ray astronomy|hard X-ray transients]] were detected between 13–16 June 2018 (event detection time)<ref name="AT-20180703a">{{cite web |author=Sharma, Y. et al. |title=AT2018cow - AstroSat CZTI limits on prompt emission |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11809 |date=3 July 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] (11809) |accessdate=3 July 2018 }}</ref> and, using the [[Astrosat#Payloads|UVIT]] fitted with a [http://uvit.iiap.res.in/Instrument/Filters F172M filter], observed an AB magnitude of an estimated 17.6 at the AT2018cow location on 3 July 2018.<ref name="AT-20180706">{{cite web |last1=Singh |first1=Avinash |last2=Bhalerao |first2=Varun |last3=Mondal |first3=Chayan |last4=Sahu |first4=Snehalata |title=AstroSat UVIT Observations of AT2018cow |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11822 |date=6 July 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] (11822) |accessdate=6 July 2018 }}</ref> Moreover, astronomers on 3 July 2018 reported, using the [[MAXI (ISS Experiment)|MAXI GSC detector]] aboard the [[International Space Station|ISS]], that no significant [[X-ray astronomy|X-ray emissions]] were detected between 11–21 June 2018.<ref name="AT-20180703">{{cite web |author=Sugizaki, M. et al. |title=AT2018cow: MAXI GSC data search |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11810 |date=3 July 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] (11810) |accessdate=3 July 2018 }}</ref> On 4 July 2018, astronomers, using [[NuSTAR]], reported a lessening of [[X-ray#Soft and hard X-rays|hard X-ray emissions]] from AT2018cow.<ref name="AT-20180704">{{cite web |author=Grefenstette, B. et al. |title=Evidence for fading of the hard X-ray emission from AT2018cow |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11813 |date=4 July 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] (11813) |accessdate=4 July 2018 }}</ref> On 12 July 2018, astronomers, using [[INTEGRAL]], reported no detections of the source from 30 June – 8 July 2018; however, GRB-like bursts may have been observed earlier in the vicinity, on 12 and 15 June 2018, although association of these bursts with AT2018cow may be "disfavored".<ref name="AT-20180712">{{cite web |author=Savchenko, V. |title=INTEGRAL observations of decaying hard X-ray emission from AT2018cow |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11843 |date=12 July 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] (11843) |accessdate=12 July 2018 }}</ref>
[[Radio astronomy|Radio emissions]], at 5 GHz with a flux density of ~ 170 microJy, were detected from the location of AT2018cow on 3–4 July 2018 by [[MERLIN#e-MERLIN|e-MERLIN]];<ref name="AT-20180705">{{cite web |author=Horesh, A. et al. |title=e-MERLIN 5 GHz Observations of AT2018cow |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11819 |date=5 July 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] (11819) |accessdate=5 July 2018 }}</ref> radio emissions at the AT2018cow location were detected by [[Australia Telescope Compact Array|ATCA]] at 5.5 GHz with ~0.4 mJy flux density and at 9 GHz with ~1.0 mJy on 3 July 2018, and at 34 GHz with ~10 mJy on 5 July 2018.<ref name="AT-20180717atca">{{cite web |author=Dobie, Dougal et al. |title=AT2018cow: Continued ATCA monitoring |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11862 |date=17 July 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] (11862) |accessdate=17 July 2018 }}</ref> [[Very-long-baseline interferometry|VLBI]] observations at 22 GHz, with the [[National Radio Astronomy Observatory|NRAO]], using the [[Very Long Baseline Array|VLBA]] and [[Effelsberg 100-m Radio Telescope|Effelsberg]] [[radio telescope]]s, found a total flux density of ~5 mJy around 8 July 2018 at a reportedly more accurate (but consistent within uncertainties) [[Astrometry|astrometric]] location of AT2018cow (RA=16h 16m 00.2242s, DEC=22d 16' 04.890") than that of e-MERLIN.<ref name="AT-20180731">{{cite web |author=Bietenholz, M. et al. |title=VLBI Detection and Astrometry for AT2018cow |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11900 |date=31 July 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] (11900) |accessdate=1 August 2018 }}</ref><ref name="AT-20180705" />
On 10 July 2018, astronomers, based on followup studies with the {{convert|2.56|m|in|abbr=on}} [[Nordic Optical Telescope]] (NOT), formally described AT2018cow as SN 2018cow and as a [[Supernova#Type I|type Ib supernova]], showing an "unprecedented spectrum for a supernova of this class".<ref name="AT-20180710">{{cite web |author=Benetti S. et al |title=NUTS update on the spectroscopic follow-up of SN 2018cow |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11836 |date=10 July 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] |accessdate=10 July 2018 }}</ref> On 19 July 2018, astronomers, using the {{convert|1.5|m|in|abbr=on}} Kanata telescope at the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:%E6%9D%B1%E5%BA%83%E5%B3%B6%E5%B8%82%E5%A4%A9%E6%96%87%E5%8F%B0_Higashi-Hiroshima_Astronomical_observatory_-_panoramio.jpg Higashi-Hiroshima Observatory], observed further declines in the optical and near-infrared luminosity of the AT2018cow position in early July 2018, and noted that the large decline rates of the light curves were "quite large" compared to Type Ic (Ic-BL) and Type Ib/c supernovae.<ref name="AT-20180719my">{{cite web |author=Yamanaka, M. et al. |title=Kanata Optical and Near-infrared Observations of AT 2018cow |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11868 |date=19 July 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] (11868) |accessdate=19 July 2018 }}</ref>
On 6 August 2018, [[Ultraviolet astronomy|ultraviolet observations]] of the AT2018cow location, using the [[Wide Field Camera 3]] (WFC3) on the [[Hubble Space Telescope]] (HST), detected brightness ([[Magnitude (astronomy)#Other scales|Vega mag]]) of about 19 on all four bands (F218W, F225W, F275W, F336W) studied.<ref name="AT-20180806cdk">{{cite web |author=Kilpatrick, C.D. et al. |title=HST/WFC3 Ultraviolet Observations of AT2018cow |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11921 |date=6 August 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] (11921) |accessdate=6 August 2018 }}</ref> On 12 August 2018, astronomers at the [[Giant Metrewave Radio Telescope]] (GMRT) detected a low frequency radio emission (1390 MHz band; 438+/-82 uJy) at the AT2018cow position.<ref name="AT-20180814">{{cite web |last1=Nayana |first1=A.J. |last2=Chandra |first2=Poonam |title=Low frequency detection of AT2018cow with the GMRT |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11950 |date=14 August 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] (11950) |accessdate=14 August 2018 }}</ref>
On 15 August 2018, astronomers using the [[High Energy Stereoscopic System]] (H.E.S.S.) array of [[Cherenkov Telescope Array|Cherenkov telescopes]] (CTA) reported no significant gamma-ray source at the AT2018cow location on 3–5 July 2018, which, as a consequence, resulted in the preliminary determination of upper limits on the integrated flux of the Very-High-Energy (VHE) gamma emission from AT2018cow as follows: above the energy threshold 220 GeV (±2sd) an upper limit of 5e-12 ph cm^-2 s^-1; above 1 TeV (±2sd) an upper limit of 5e-13 ph cm^-2 s^-1.<ref name="AT-20180815">{{cite web |last=de Naurois |first=Mathieu |title=H.E.S.S. upper limits on VHE gamma emission from AT2018cow |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11956 |date=15 August 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] (11956) |accessdate=15 August 2018 }}</ref>
==Properties== According to astronomers at the time of its discovery, the explosion, with a surface temperature of over {{convert|8900|C|F K|sigfig=2}} and traveling {{convert|20,000|km/s|mi/s|abbr=on}},<ref name="TECH-20180626" /> may have been a [[cataclysmic variable star]] (CV), [[gamma-ray burst]] (GRB), [[gravitational wave]] (GW), [[supernova]] (SN), or something else.<ref name="AT-20180617">{{cite journal |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=11727 |title=ATLAS18qqn (AT2018cow) - a bright transient spatially coincident with CGCG 137-068 (60 Mpc) |journal=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] |first1=S. J. |last1=Smartt |first2=P. |last2=Clark |first3=K. W. |last3=Smith |first4=O. |last4=McBrien |first5=K. |last5=Maguire |first6=D. |last6=O'Neil |first7=M. |last7=Fulton |first8=M. |last8=Magee |first9=S. |last9=Prentice |first10=C. |last10=Colin |first11=J. |last11=Tonry |first12=L. |last12=Denneau |first13=B. |last13=Stalder |first14=A. |last14=Heinze |first15=H. |last15=Weiland |first16=H. |last16=Flewelling |first17=A. |last17=Rest |display-authors=1 |issue=11727 |date=17 June 2018 |accessdate=22 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="NS-20180621">{{cite news |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/2172351-weve-just-seen-a-huge-space-explosion-and-dont-know-what-it-is/ |title=We've just seen a huge space explosion and don't know what it is |work=[[New Scientist]] |last=Crane |first=Leah |date=21 June 2018 |accessdate=22 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="WP-20180625">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/speaking-of-science/wp/2018/06/25/ive-never-seen-anything-like-this-astronomers-dazzled-by-brilliant-supernova/ |title='I've never seen anything like this': Astronomers dazzled by brilliant supernova |work=[[The Washington Post]] |last=Kaplan |first=Sarah |date=25 June 2018 |accessdate=25 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="INQ-20180622">{{cite news |url=https://www.inquisitr.com/4954089/an-explosion-has-rocked-space-200-million-light-years-from-earth-and-scientists-are-unsure-what-is-causing-it/ |title=An Explosion Has Rocked Space 200 Million Light Years From Earth And Scientists Are Unsure What Is Causing It |work=Inquisitr |first=Kristine |last=Moore |date=22 June 2018 |accessdate=25 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="MN-20180622">{{cite news |url=https://en.mogaznews.com/Technology/943442/Mystery-of-the-massive-explosion-200-light-years-away.html |title=Mystery of the massive explosion 200 light years away |work=Mogaznews |date=22 June 2018 |accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref> According to astronomer Kate Maguire of [[Queen's University Belfast]]: "It really just appeared out of nowhere. There are other objects that have been discovered that are as fast, but the fastness and the brightness, that's quite unusual."<ref name="INQ-20180622" />
The classification of type Ic-BL indicates a spectrum with very unusually broad [[spectral line|lines]], but with no hydrogen lines and weak or missing helium lines. Such a spectrum is produced by the explosion of a very large star which has lost its outer layers of [[hydrogen]] and [[helium]].<ref name="TH-20180701">{{cite news |last=Desikan |first=Shubashree |title=Astronomers puzzled by ‘cow’ in the sky |url=https://www.thehindu.com/sci-tech/science/astronomers-puzzled-by-cow-in-the-sky/article24300319.ece |date=1 July 2018 |work=[[The Hindu]] |accessdate=1 July 2018 }}</ref> However, according to astronomer Shubham Srivastav, associated with the {{convert|2.0|m|in|abbr=on}} [[Indian Astronomical Observatory#Himalayan Chandra Telescope|Himalayan Chandra Telescope]] (HCT): "Although spectroscopic features indicate a tentative similarity with broad line Ic supernovae, its true nature remains a puzzle."<ref name="TH-20180701" /> Also, according to Maguire: "We're not sure yet what it is, but the normal powering mechanism for a supernova is radioactive decay of [[nickel]], and this event is too bright and too fast for that."<ref name="INQ-20180622" /> The AT2018cow explosion could have been accompanied by a GW emission, but the GW emission could not be detected since the [[LIGO|LIGO detectors]] in the states of [[Washington (state)|Washington]] and [[Louisiana]] were down at the time of the event due to service upgradings.<ref name="WP-20180625" />
An explanation to help better understand the unique features of AT2018cow, particularly as a [[white dwarf]] [[tidal disruption event]], has been presented.<ref name="ARX-20180826">{{cite arxiv |author=Kuin, N. Paul M. et al. |title=Swift spectra of AT2018cow: A White Dwarf Tidal Disruption Event? |date=26 August 2018 |eprint=1808.08492 |class=astro-ph.HE }}</ref>
As of 29 September 2018, AT2018cow has been explained in various ways, including as a [[type Ic supernova]], a [[gamma-ray burst]], an interaction between a [[white dwarf]] and [[black hole]], and as a [[magnetar]]. Preliminary studies to better understand the exact physical nature of AT2018cow, using the [[European VLBI Network]] (EVN), have been presented.<ref name="AT-20180929">{{cite web |last=An |first=Tao |title=The EVN detection of AT2018cow at 1.67GHz |url=http://www.astronomerstelegram.org/?read=12067 |date=29 September 2018 |work=[[The Astronomer's Telegram]] (12068) |accessdate=29 September 2018 }}</ref>
On 2 November 2018, two independent teams of astronomers both concluded that the AT2018cow event was "either a newly formed [[black hole]] in the process of accreting matter, or the frenetic rotation of a [[neutron star]]."<ref name="NAT-20181102">{{cite journal |last=Castelvecchi |first=Davide |title=Holy Cow! Astronomers agog at mysterious new supernova - An event known as 'Cow' that has rocked astronomy since June likely offers a close look at the birth of a neutron star or black hole. |url=https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-018-07260-w |date=2 November 2018 |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=563 |issue=7730 |pages=168–169 |doi=10.1038/d41586-018-07260-w |pmid=30401847 |accessdate=2 November 2018 }}</ref><ref name="ARX-20181025">{{cite arxiv |author=Margutti, Raffaella et al. |title=An embedded X-ray source shines through the aspherical AT2018cow: revealing the inner workings of the most luminous fast-evolving optical transients |date=25 October 2018 |eprint=1810.10720 |class=astro-ph.HE }}</ref><ref name="ARX-20181028">{{cite arxiv |author=Ho Anna Y. Q. et al. |title=AT2018cow: a luminous millimeter transient |date=28 October 2018 |eprint=1810.10880 |class=astro-ph.HE }}</ref><ref name="ARX-20180812">{{cite arxiv |author=Perley, Daniel A. et al. |title=The Fast, Luminous Ultraviolet Transient AT2018cow: Extreme Supernova, or Disruption of a Star by an Intermediate-Mass Black Hole? |date=12 August 2018 |eprint=1808.00969 |class=astro-ph.HE }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Superluminous supernova]], a supernova at least ten times more [[Luminosity|luminous]] than a standard [[supernova]]
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== * [https://wis-tns.weizmann.ac.il/object/2018cow AT2018cow webpage] on the Transient Name Server * [http://astro.vanbuitenen.nl/transient/3653 AT2018cow webpage] at Vanbuitenen.nl * [http://www.rochesterastronomy.org/sn2018/sn2018cow.html AT2018cow webpage] by the Astronomy Section Rochester Academy of Science * [http://ned.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?objname=CGCG+137-068&img_stamp=YES&list_limit=9&extend=no CGCG 137-068 webpage] at the [[NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database]] * [https://www.flickr.com/photos/152958240@N05/29076418508/ AT2018cow images from 21 June 2018] by Cedric Raguenaud * {{youtube|HALyrwfM25c|AT2018cow – Summary – audio (german/en subs; 03:50)}} * {{youtube|HlFENEC9hss|AT2018cow – Wikipedia lede – audio (01:00)}} {{2018 in space}} {{portal bar|Astronomy|Cosmology|Physics}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}}
