revision.text:
{{short description|The innermost part of the Earth, a solid ball of iron-nickel alloy}} {{For|the cores of other planetary bodies|Planetary core}} {{broader|Structure of the Earth#Core}} [[File:Earth poster.svg|thumb|upright=1.4|The internal structure of Earth]]
The [[Earth|Earth's]] '''inner core''' is the Earth's innermost part. It is primarily a [[solid]] [[ball (mathematics)|ball]] with a [[radius]] of about {{convert|1220|km|mi|abbr=off}}, which is about 70% of the [[Moon]]'s radius.<ref>{{Cite journal | first1=Marc | last1=Monnereau | first2=Marie | last2=Calvet | first3=Ludovic | last3=Margerin | first4=Annie | last4=Souriau | title=Lopsided Growth of Earth's Inner Core | journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] | date=May 21, 2010 | volume=328 | issue=5981 | pages=1014–1017 | doi=10.1126/science.1186212 | bibcode=2010Sci...328.1014M | pmid=20395477 | postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = E. R. Engdahl | author2 = E. A. Flynn | author3 = R. P. Massé | lastauthoramp=yes | title = Differential PkiKP travel times and the radius of the core | journal = Geophys. J. R. Astron. Soc.| volume = 40 | issue = 3 | pages = 457–463 | date = 1974 | doi = 10.1111/j.1365-246X.1974.tb05467.x|bibcode = 1974GeoJ...39..457E }}</ref> It is composed of an [[iron–nickel alloy]] and some other elements. The temperature at the inner core's surface is approximately {{convert|5700|K|C}} or 9806 °F, which is about the temperature at the [[Photosphere#Sun|surface of the Sun]].<ref name="alfè">{{cite journal | author = D. Alfè | author2 = M. Gillan | author3 = G. D. Price | lastauthoramp=yes | title = Composition and temperature of the Earth's core constrained by combining ab initio calculations and seismic data | journal = Earth and Planetary Science Letters | volume = 195 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 91–98 | publisher = [[Elsevier]] | date = January 30, 2002 | url = http://www.homepages.ucl.ac.uk/~ucfbdxa/pubblicazioni/epsl2002.pdf |format=PDF| doi = 10.1016/S0012-821X(01)00568-4 | bibcode=2002E&PSL.195...91A}}</ref>
==Discovery== The Earth was discovered to have a solid inner core distinct from its molten [[outer core]] in 1936, by the Danish seismologist [[Inge Lehmann]],<ref>{{cite book|editor=Edmond A. Mathez |title=EARTH: INSIDE AND OUT |date=2000 |publisher=American Museum of Natural History |url=http://www.amnh.org/education/resources/rfl/web/essaybooks/earth/p_lehmann.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080430105106/http://www.amnh.org/education/resources/rfl/web/essaybooks/earth/p_lehmann.html |archivedate=2008-04-30 |df= }}</ref> who deduced its presence by studying seismograms from earthquakes in New Zealand. She observed that the [[seismic wave]]s reflect off the boundary of the inner core and can be detected by sensitive [[seismographs]] on the Earth's surface. This boundary is known as the [[Keith Edward Bullen|Bullen]] discontinuity,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uh.edu/~jbutler/physical/chapter19notes.html |title=Class Notes – The Earth's Interior |author=John C. Butler |date=1995 |work=Physical Geology Grade Book |publisher=[[University of Houston]] |accessdate=30 August 2011}}</ref> or sometimes as the Lehmann discontinuity.<ref>Although [[Lehmann discontinuity|another discontinuity]] is named after Lehmann, this usage still can be found: see for example: {{cite book |title=The basics of earth science |author=Robert E Krebs |date=2003 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Company |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-4ndyH7u6T0C&pg=PA142 |isbn=0-313-31930-8}},and [http://geology.about.com/library/weekly/aa031598.htm ''From here to "hevean," or the D layer''], About.com</ref> A few years later, in 1940, it was hypothesized that this inner core was made of solid iron; its rigidity was confirmed in 1971.<ref name=Lee>{{cite book |title=International Handbook of Earthquake and Engineering Seismology; part A |editor1-last=Lee |editor1-first=William H. K. |editor2-last=Kanamori |editor2-first=Hiroo |editor3-last=Jennings |editor3-first=Paul C. |editor4-last=Kisslinger |editor4-first=Carl |page=926 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aFNKqnC2E-sC&pg=PA926 |date=2002 |publisher=Academic Press |isbn=0-12-440652-1}}</ref>
The [[outer core]] was determined to be molten from observations showing that [[compressional wave]]s pass through it, but elastic [[simple shear|shear]] waves do not – or do so only very weakly.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/1996/08.15/PuttingaNewSpin.html | title = Putting a New Spin on Earth's Core | author = William J. Cromie | date = 1996-08-15 | publisher = Harvard Gazette | accessdate = 2007-05-22}}</ref> The solidity of the inner core had been difficult to establish because the elastic [[shear wave]]s that are expected to pass through a solid mass are very weak and difficult for seismographs on the Earth's surface to detect, since they become so attenuated on their way from the inner core to the surface by their passage through the liquid outer core. Dziewonski and Gilbert established that measurements of [[normal modes|normal modes of vibration]] of Earth caused by large earthquakes were consistent with a liquid outer core.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Solidity of the Inner Core of the Earth inferred from Normal Mode Observations |author1=A. M. Dziewonski |author2=F. Gilbert | journal = Nature | volume = 234 | issue = 5330 | pages = 465–466 | date = 1971-12-24 | doi = 10.1038/234465a0 |bibcode = 1971Natur.234..465D }}</ref> In 2005, shear waves were detected passing through the inner core; these claims were initially controversial, but are now gaining acceptance.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.livescience.com/environment/050414_earth_core.html| title = Finally, a Solid Look at Earth's Core | author = Robert Roy Britt | accessdate = 2007-05-22 | date = 2005-04-14}}</ref>
==Composition== Based on the relative prevalence of various chemical elements in the [[Solar System]], the theory of [[Formation and evolution of the Solar System#Terrestrial planets|planetary formation]], and constraints imposed or implied by the chemistry of the rest of the Earth's volume, the inner core is believed to consist primarily of a [[Iron–nickel alloy|nickel-iron alloy]]. Pure iron was found to be denser than the core by approximately 3%, implying the presence of light elements in the core (e.g. silicon, oxygen, sulfur) in addition to the probable presence of nickel.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Stixrude|first=Lars|last2=Wasserman|first2=Evgeny|last3=Cohen|first3=Ronald E.|date=1997-11-10|title=Composition and temperature of Earth's inner core|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/97JB02125/abstract|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth|language=en|volume=102|issue=B11|pages=24729–24739|doi=10.1029/97JB02125|issn=2156-2202|bibcode=1997JGR...10224729S}}</ref>
Further, if the [[History of Earth|primordial]] and mostly ''[[fluid]]'' ([[Protoplanetary disk|still forming]]) earth contained any significant mass(es) of elements denser than iron and nickel, namely the [[White metal|white]] (appearance) [[precious metals]] (and a few others) ''except'' silver, specifically the [[siderophile element]]s, then these would necessarily have differentiated to the very center of the core into concentric nested spheres by [[Planetary differentiation|planetary differentiation]], with the most dense (and [[Stable nuclide|stable]], i.e. [[platinum]], [[iridium]], and [[osmium]], (etc.) in order of density) of these forming the innermost spheroid(s).<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.nationalgeographic.org/encyclopedia/core/ | title = core – National Geographic Society}}</ref> While ''unstable'' elements of such trans-iron/nickel density would have mostly [[radioactive decay|decayed]] to iron/nickel/lead by the time the earth formed a discrete core. {{see also|Densities of the elements (data page)}} It then necessarily follows that all, or almost all, of these denser elements we have mined (or are even able to) at the surface (or near surface, or even at all "above" the core) have been delivered later as part of [[Impact event|impact objects/masses]].<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.universetoday.com/18406/earths-precious-metals-could-be-from-meteorites-and-asteroids/ | title = Earth’s Precious Metals Could Be From Meteorites and Asteroids}}</ref>
==Temperature and pressure== The temperature of the inner core can be estimated by considering both the theoretical and the experimentally demonstrated constraints on the melting temperature of impure iron at the pressure which iron is under at the boundary of the inner core (about 330 [[GPa]]). These considerations suggest that its temperature is about {{convert|5700|K|sigfig=2}}.<ref name="alfè">{{cite journal | author = D. Alfè | author2 = M. Gillan | author3 = G. D. Price | lastauthoramp=yes | title = Composition and temperature of the Earth's core constrained by combining ab initio calculations and seismic data | journal = Earth and Planetary Science Letters | volume = 195 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 91–98 | publisher = [[Elsevier]] | date = January 30, 2002 | url = http://www.homepages.ucl.ac.uk/~ucfbdxa/pubblicazioni/epsl2002.pdf |format=PDF| doi = 10.1016/S0012-821X(01)00568-4 | bibcode=2002E&PSL.195...91A}}</ref> The pressure in the Earth's inner core is slightly higher than it is at the boundary between the outer and inner cores: it ranges from about {{convert|330|to|360|GPa|atm}}.<ref name="crc">{{cite book | editor = David. R. Lide | title = CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics | pages = j14–13 | edition = 87th | date = 2006–2007 | url = http://hbcpnetbase.com/ }}</ref> Iron can be solid at such high temperatures only because its melting temperature increases dramatically at pressures of that magnitude (see the [[Clausius–Clapeyron relation]]).<ref>{{cite journal | author = Anneli Aitta | title = Iron melting curve with a tricritical point | journal = Journal of Statistical Mechanics: Theory and Experiment | volume = 2006 | issue = 12 | date = 2006-12-01 | pages = 12015–12030 | publisher = iop | url = http://stacks.iop.org/JSTAT/2006/P12015 | doi = 10.1088/1742-5468/2006/12/P12015 |arxiv = cond-mat/0701283 |bibcode = 2006JSMTE..12..015A }} or see preprints https://arxiv.org/pdf/cond-mat/0701283 , https://arxiv.org/pdf/0807.0187 .</ref>
A report published in the journal ''Science'' <ref>{{cite journal | author = S. Anzellini | author2 = A. Dewaele | author3 = M. Mezouar | author4 = P. Loubeyre | author5 = G. Morard | lastauthoramp=yes | title = Melting of Iron at Earth’s Inner Core Boundary Based on Fast X-ray Diffraction | journal = Science | volume = 340 | issue = 6136 | date = 2013 | pages = 464–466 | publisher = AAAS | url = http://www.sciencemag.org/content/340/6131/464 | doi = 10.1126/science.1233514| bibcode = 2013Sci...340..464A }}</ref> concludes that the melting temperature of iron at the inner core boundary is 6230 ± 500 K.
==Dynamics== The Earth's inner core is thought to be slowly growing as the liquid [[outer core]] at the boundary with the inner core cools and solidifies due to the gradual cooling of the Earth's interior (about 100 degrees Celsius per billion years).<ref name=Jacobs>{{cite journal | author = J.A. Jacobs | title = The Earth's inner core | journal = Nature | volume = 172 | issue = 4372 | pages = 297–298 | date = 1953 | doi = 10.1038/172297a0|bibcode = 1953Natur.172..297J }}</ref> Many scientists had initially expected that the inner core would be found to be [[Homogeneous mixture|homogeneous]], because the solid inner core was originally formed by a gradual cooling of molten material, and continues to grow as a result of that same process. Even though it is growing into liquid, it is solid, due to the very high pressure that keeps it compacted together even if the temperature is extremely high. It was even suggested that Earth's inner core might be a [[single crystal]] of iron.<ref>{{cite journal | first=William J. | last= Broad | title = The Core of the Earth May Be a Gigantic Crystal Made of Iron | journal = NY Times | volume = | pages = | date = 1995-04-04 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/04/science/the-core-of-the-earth-may-be-a-gigantic-crystal-made-of-iron.html?pagewanted=all | accessdate= 2010-12-21 | issn=0362-4331 }}</ref> However, this prediction was disproved by observations indicating that in fact there is a degree of disorder within the inner core.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.berkeley.edu/news/media/releases/96legacy/iron.html|title=Earth's inner core not a monolithic iron crystal, say UC Berkeley seismologist|author=Robert Sanders|date=1996-11-13|accessdate=2007-05-22}}</ref> Seismologists have found that the inner core is not completely uniform, but instead contains large-scale structures such that seismic waves pass more rapidly through some parts of the inner core than through others.<ref>{{Cite journal|journal=Nature|volume=413|pages=27–30|date=2001-09-06|doi=10.1038/35092650|title=Earth science: Core beliefs|author1=Andrew Jephcoat |author2=Keith Refson |pmid=11544508|issue=6851 |bibcode=2001Natur.413...27J}}</ref> In addition, the properties of the inner core's surface vary from place to place across distances as small as 1 km. This variation is surprising, since lateral temperature variations along the inner-core boundary are known to be extremely small (this conclusion is confidently constrained by [[magnetic field]] observations). Discoveries in 1994 suggest that the solid inner core itself is composed of layers, separated by a transition zone about 250 to 400 km thick.<ref>{{Cite journal|author= Kazuro Hirahara|author2=Toshiki Ohtaki |author3=Yasuhiro Yoshida | lastauthoramp=yes |title=Seismic structure near the inner core-outer core boundary|journal= Geophys. Res. Lett.|volume=51|pages=157–160|publisher=[[American Geophysical Union]]|date=1994|url=http://www.agu.org/pubs/crossref/1994/93GL03289.shtml|doi=10.1029/93GL03289|bibcode=1994GeoRL..21..157K|issue =16}}</ref> If the inner core grows by small frozen sediments falling onto its surface, then some liquid can also be trapped in the pore spaces and some of this residual fluid may still persist to some small degree in much of its interior.
Because the inner core is not rigidly connected to the Earth's solid [[mantle (geology)|mantle]], the possibility that it [[rotation|rotates]] slightly more quickly or slowly than the rest of Earth has long been entertained.<ref>{{Cite journal | title = Mechanics of inner core super-rotation | date = 1996 | journal = Geophysical Research Letters | pages = 3401–3404 | volume = 23 | issue = 23 | last1 = Aaurno | first1 = J. M. | last2 = Brito | first2 = D. | last3 = Olson | first3 = P. L. |bibcode = 1996GeoRL..23.3401A |doi = 10.1029/96GL03258 | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}} }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | title = Evidence for inner core super-rotation from time-dependent differential PKP traveltimes observed at Beijing Seismic Network | date = 2003 | journal = [[Geophysical Journal International]] | pages = 509–514 | volume = 152 | issue = 3 | doi = 10.1046/j.1365-246X.2003.01852.x | last1 = Xu | first1 = Xiaoxia | last2 = Song | first2 = Xiaodong |bibcode = 2003GeoJI.152..509X | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}} | citeseerx = 10.1.1.210.8362}}</ref> In the 1990s, seismologists made various claims about detecting this kind of super-rotation by observing changes in the characteristics of [[seismic waves]] passing through the inner core over several decades, using the aforementioned property that it transmits waves more quickly in some directions. Estimates of this super-rotation are around one degree of extra rotation per year.
Growth of the inner core is thought to play an important role in the generation of [[Earth's magnetic field]] by [[Dynamo theory|dynamo]] action in the liquid outer core. This occurs mostly because it cannot dissolve the same amount of light elements as the outer core and therefore freezing at the inner core boundary produces a residual liquid that contains more light elements than the overlying liquid. This causes it to become [[buoyant]] and helps drive convection of the outer core.{{Citation needed|date=May 2007}} The existence of the inner core also changes the dynamic motions of liquid in the outer core as it grows and may help fix the magnetic field since it is expected to be a great deal more resistant to flow than the outer core liquid (which is expected to be turbulent).{{Citation needed|date=May 2007}}
Speculation also continues that the inner core might have exhibited a variety of internal [[Deformation (engineering)|deformation]] patterns. This may be necessary to explain why seismic waves pass more rapidly in some directions than in others.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=G Poupinet |author2=R Pillet |author3=A Souriau | title = Possible heterogeneity of the Earth's core deduced from PKIKP travel times | journal = Nature | volume = 305| pages = 204–206 | date = 1983 | doi=10.1038/305204a0|bibcode=1983Natur.305..204P }}</ref> Because [[thermal convection]] alone appears to be improbable,<ref>{{cite journal | author = T. Yukutake | title = Implausibility of thermal convection in the Earth's solid inner core | journal = Phys. Earth Planet. Inter. | volume = 108 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–13 | date = 1998 | doi = 10.1016/S0031-9201(98)00097-1 | bibcode=1998PEPI..108....1Y}}</ref> any buoyant convection motions will have to be driven by variations in composition or abundance of liquid in its interior. S. Yoshida and colleagues proposed a novel mechanism whereby deformation of the inner core can be caused by a higher rate of freezing at the equator than at polar latitudes,<ref>{{cite journal | author = S.I. Yoshida | author2 = I. Sumita | author3 = M. Kumazawa | lastauthoramp=yes | title = Growth model of the inner core coupled with the outer core dynamics and the resulting elastic anisotropy | journal = Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth | volume = 101 | pages = 28085–28103 | date = 1996 | doi = 10.1029/96JB02700 | bibcode=1996JGR...10128085Y}}</ref> and S. Karato proposed that changes in the magnetic field might also deform the inner core slowly over time.<ref>{{cite journal | author = S. I. Karato | title = Seismic anisotropy of the Earth's inner core resulting from flow induced by Maxwell stresses | journal = Nature | volume = 402 | issue = 6764 | pages = 871–873 | date = 1999 | doi = 10.1038/47235|bibcode = 1999Natur.402..871K }}</ref>
There is an East–West asymmetry in the inner core seismological data. There is a model which explains this by differences at the surface of the inner core – melting in one hemisphere and crystallization in the other.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Alboussière | first1 = T. | last2 = Deguen | first2 = R. | last3 = Melzani | first3 = M.| title = Melting-induced stratification above the Earth's inner core due to convective translation | journal = Nature | volume = 466 | issue = 7307 | pages = 744–747 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20686572 | doi = 10.1038/nature09257|bibcode = 2010Natur.466..744A |arxiv = 1201.1201 }}</ref> The western hemisphere of the inner core may be crystallizing, whereas the eastern hemisphere may be melting. This may lead to enhanced magnetic field generation in the crystallizing hemisphere, creating the asymmetry in the Earth's magnetic field.<ref>[http://www.nature.com/ngeo/journal/v5/n8/fig_tab/ngeo1516_F1.html "Figure 1: East–west asymmetry in inner-core growth and magnetic field generation."] from {{cite journal | last1 = Finlay | first1 = Christopher C. | year = 2012 | title = Core processes: Earth's eccentric magnetic field | url = | journal = Nature Geoscience | volume = 5 | issue = | pages = 523–524 | doi = 10.1038/ngeo1516 | bibcode = 2012NatGe...5..523F }}</ref>
==History== {{Main article|History of Earth}}
Based on rates of cooling of the core, it is estimated that the current solid inner core started solidifying approximately 0.5 to 2 billion years ago<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Labrosse|first=Stéphane|last2=Poirier|first2=Jean-Paul|last3=Le Mouël|first3=Jean-Louis|date=2001-08-15|title=The age of the inner core|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0012821X01003879|journal=Earth and Planetary Science Letters|volume=190|issue=3–4|pages=111–123|doi=10.1016/S0012-821X(01)00387-9|bibcode=2001E&PSL.190..111L}}</ref> out of a fully molten core (which formed just after [[Planetary core|planetary formation]]). If true, this would mean that the Earth's solid inner core is not a primordial feature that was present during the planet's formation, but a feature younger than the Earth (the Earth is about 4.5 billion years old).
==See also== {{Wikibooks |Historical Geology|Structure of the Earth}} * [[Geodynamics]] * [[Iron meteorite]] * [[Structure of the Earth]] * [[Travel to the Earth's center]]

Jacobs | title = The Earth's inner core | journal = Nature | volume = 172 | issue = 4372 | pages = 297–298 | date = 1953 | doi = 10.1038/172297a0|bibcode = 1953Natur.172..297J }}</ref> --> }}

{{refimprove|date=September 2012}} [[File:LIquid switches (Modern Electrical Practice, Vol 2).jpg|thumb|Liquid rheostats used as motor start switches, circa 1900]] A '''liquid rheostat''' or '''water rheostat''' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://encyclopedia2.thefreedictionary.com/liquid+rheostat |title=liquid rheostat definition of liquid rheostat in the Free Online Encyclopedia |publisher=Encyclopedia2.thefreedictionary.com |date= |accessdate=2013-04-09}}</ref> or '''salt water rheostat''' is a type of [[variable resistor]]. This may be used as a [[dummy load]] or as a starting resistor for large slip ring motors.
In the simplest form it consists of a tank containing [[brine]] or other electrolyte solution, in which [[electrode]]s are submerged to create an [[electrical load]]. The electrodes may be raised or lowered into the liquid to respectively decrease or increase the [[electrical resistance]] of the load. To stabilize the load, the mixture must not be allowed to boil.
Modern designs use stainless steel electrodes, and sodium carbonate, or other salts, and do not use the container as one electrode. In some designs the electrodes are fixed and the liquid is raised and lowered by an external cylinder or pump. Motor start systems with a rapid starting cadenza may include water circulation to external heat exchangers. In such cases anti-freeze and anti-corrosion additives must be carefully chosen to not change the resistance or support the growth of algae or bacteria.
The salt water rheostat operates at unity [[power factor]] and presents a resistance with negligible series inductance compared to a wire wound equivalent, and was widely used by generator assemblers, until 20 years ago, as a matter of course. They are still sometimes constructed on-site for the commissioning of large diesel generators in remote places, where discarded [[oil drums]] and [[Tube and clamp scaffold|scaffold tubes]] may form an improvised tank and electrodes.
==Description==
Typically a traditional liquid rheostat consists of a steel cylinder (the [[cathode|negative]]), about {{convert|5|ft|m}} in size, standing on insulators, in which was suspended a hollow steel cylinder. This acted as the [[anode|positive electrode]] and was supported by a steel rope and insulator from an adjustable pulley. The water pipe connection included an insulated section. The tank contained salt water, but not at the concentration that could be described as “brine”. The whole device was fenced off for safety.
Operation was very simple, as adding more salt, more water or varying the height of the centre electrode would vary the load.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chestofbooks.com/crafts/scientific-american/sup7/Liquid-Rheostats.html |title=Liquid Rheostats |publisher=Chestofbooks.com |date= |accessdate=2013-04-09}}</ref> The load proved to be quite stable, varying only slightly as the water heated up. It never came to the boil. Power dissipation was about 1 [[megawatt]], at a potential of about 700 [[volt]]s and current of about 1,500 [[ampere]]s.
Modern designs use stainless steel electrodes, and sodium carbonate, or other salts, and do not use the container as one electrode.
Systems with a rapid starting cadenza{{huh|date=March 2018}} may include water circulation to external heat exchangers. In such cases anti-freeze and anti-corrosion additives must be carefully chosen to not change the resistance or support the growth of algae or bacteria.
==Advantages and disadvantages== An advantage is silent operation, with none of the fan noise of current [[Load bank#Resistive load bank|resistive grid designs]].
Disadvantages include: * corrosion to the copper connection cables and to the wire rope * lack of insulation from ground which may trip a [[Residual-current device|ground detection system]]
==Uses== Railways commonly used salt water load banks in the 1950s to test the output power of [[diesel-electric locomotive]]s.<ref>United States Army, ''Operation and Maintenance of Diesel-Electric Locomotives TM 55-202'', 965, page 240</ref> They were subsequently replaced by specially designed resistive [[load bank]]s. These later designs, rated for {{convert|4000|hp|kW}}, currently cost in the region of 100,000 to 180,000 [[euro]]. Hence, it is economically advantageous for railways to build their own salt-water type. Some electric locomotives also used liquid rheostats, in particular in Italy for early three-phase AC types such as the [[FS Class E550]]. Some direct current designs also used them as starting resistors.
Liquid rheostats were sometimes used in large (thousands of kilowatts/horsepower) [[wound rotor motor]] drives, to control the rotor circuit resistance and so the speed of the motor. Electrode position could be adjusted with a small electrically operated winch or a pneumatic cylinder. A cooling pump and heat exchanger were provided to allow slip energy to be dissipated into process water or other water system.<ref>[[Igor Karassik]] et al, (ed), ''Pump Handbook Fourth Edition'', Mc Graw Hill 2008, {{ISBN|978-0-07-146044-6}} pages 9-113 -9-115</ref>
==Current use== High voltage distribution networks use fixed electrolyte resistors to ground the neutral, to provide a current limiting action, so that the voltage across the ground during fault is kept to a safe level. Unlike a solid resistor, the liquid resistor is self healing in the event of overload. Normally the resistance is set up during commissioning, and then left fixed.<ref>http://www.acrastyle.co.uk/products/liquid-neutral-earthing-resistors/</ref>
Modern motor starters <ref>http://www.aoip.com/product/epm/</ref> are totally enclosed and the electrode movement is servo motor controlled. Typically a 1 tonne tank will start a 1 megawatt slip ring type motor, but there is considerable variation in start time depending on application.
==Safety issues with older designs== The fully salt-water load bank dates from an earlier, less regulated and litigious era.<!-- Not "unsafe era" also? --> To pass current safety legislation requires more enclosed designs.
They are no more dangerous than [[electrode heater]]s, which work on the same principle, but with plain water, or electrical immersion heaters, provided the correct precautions are used. This requires connecting the container to both ground and neutral and breaking all poles with a linked over-current [[circuit breaker]]. If in the open, [[safety barrier]]s are required.
==See also== * [[Liquid resistor]] * [[BS 7671]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}}[[File:Hurricane Isabel from ISS.jpg|300px|right|thumb|[[Hurricane Isabel]], as seen from the [[International Space Station]] in September 2003.]] This is a '''List of Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes'''. A total of 33 recorded [[tropical cyclone]]s have reached Category 5 strength on the [[Saffir–Simpson hurricane wind scale]] in the [[Atlantic Ocean]] north of the [[equator]], the [[Caribbean Sea]], and the [[Gulf of Mexico]]. Hurricanes of such intensity occur once every three years in this region on average. Only in six seasons—[[1932 Atlantic hurricane season|1932]], [[1933 Atlantic hurricane season|1933]], [[1961 Atlantic hurricane season|1961]], [[2005 Atlantic hurricane season|2005]], [[2007 Atlantic hurricane season|2007]], and [[2017 Atlantic hurricane season|2017]]—has more than one Category 5 hurricane formed. Only in 2005 have more than two Category 5 hurricanes formed, and only in 2007 and 2017 did more than one make landfall at Category 5 strength.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} ==Background== {{Saffir-Simpson small}} [[File:Map of Atlantic Category Five hurricanes.png|thumb|left|300px|Tracks of all known Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes between 1851 and 2014]] A Category 5 Atlantic hurricane is one that is considered by the United States [[National Hurricane Center]] (NHC), to have had sustained wind speeds greater than {{convert|136|kn|mph km/h m/s}} on the [[Saffir–Simpson scale]]. The NHC considers sustained wind speeds to be those that occur over a one-minute period at {{convert|10|m|1}} above ground. These wind speeds are estimated by using a blend of data from a variety of sources, which include observations from nearby ships, reconnaissance aircraft, or automatic weather stations and pictures from various satellites. Officially, from [[1924 Atlantic hurricane season|1924]] to [[2017 Atlantic hurricane season|2017]], 33 Category 5 hurricanes have been recorded. No Category 5 hurricanes were observed officially before 1924. It can be presumed that earlier storms reached Category 5 strength over open waters, but the strongest winds were not measured. The [[anemometer]], a device used for measuring wind speed, was invented in 1846. However, during major hurricane strikes, the instruments as a whole were often blown away, leaving the hurricane's peak intensity unrecorded. For example, as the [[Great Beaufort Hurricane]] of 1879 struck North Carolina, the anemometer cups were blown away when indicating {{convert|138|mph|km/h|abbr=on|lk=off}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/er/rnk/Research/NC_Tropical_Cyclone_History.pdf|title=Tropical cyclones affecting North Carolina since 1586|last=Hudgins|first=James E.|date=|year=2000|work=National Weather Service Office Blacksburg, Virginia|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611220124/http://www.erh.noaa.gov/er/rnk/Research/NC_Tropical_Cyclone_History.pdf|archivedate=June 11, 2011|deadurl=yes|accessdate=November 25, 2010|df=}} {{As of|2018|May}}, a [[Atlantic hurricane reanalysis|reanalysis]] of weather data was ongoing by researchers who may upgrade or downgrade other Atlantic hurricanes currently listed at Categories 4 and 5.{{cite web|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/data_sub/re_anal.html|title=Current Hurricane Data Sets|author=Atlantic Oceanographic & Meterological Laboratory|first=|date=June 8, 2010|work=Hurricane Research Division|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=November 1, 2018|quote=The Atlantic Hurricane Database Re-analysis Project is an effort to extend and revise the National Hurricane Center's North Atlantic hurricane database (or HURDAT). Going back to 1851 and revisiting storms in more recent years, information on tropical cyclones is revised using an enhanced collection of historical meteorological data in the context of today's scientific understanding of hurricanes and analysis techniques.}} For example, the [[1825 Santa Ana hurricane]] is suspected to have reached Category 5 strength.{{cite journal|last=Donnelly|first=J. P.|date=|year=2005|title=Evidence of Past Intense Tropical Cyclones from Backbarrier Salt Pond Sediments: A Case Study from Isla de Culebrita, Puerto Rico, USA|url=http://www.whoi.edu/science/GG/coastal/publications/pdfs/Donnelly%20JCR%202005-Hurricane.pdf|journal=Journal of Coastal Research|volume=SI42|pages=201–210|issn=0749-0208|accessdate=November 26, 2010|via=}} Furthermore, [[Paleotempestology|paleotempestological]] research aims to identify past major hurricanes by comparing sedimentary evidence of recent and past hurricane strikes. For example, a "giant hurricane" significantly more powerful than [[Hurricane Hattie]] (Category 5) has been identified in [[Belize]]an sediment, having struck the region sometime [[Pre-1600 Atlantic hurricane seasons|before 1500]].{{cite journal|last=Mccloskey|first=T. A.|first2=G. |last2=Keller |year=2009|title=5000 year sedimentary record of hurricane strikes on the central coast of Belize|journal=Quaternary International|pages=53–68|issue=1–2|publisher=|volume=195|issn=1040-6182|doi=10.1016/j.quaint.2008.03.003|bibcode = 2009QuInt.195...53M }} [[File:1924 Atlantic hurricane 10 track.png|thumb|An [[1924 Cuba hurricane|October Category 5]] that hit Cuba in [[1924 Atlantic hurricane season|1924]]]] Officially, the decade with the most Category 5 hurricanes is 2000–2009, with eight Category 5 hurricanes having occurred: Isabel (2003), Ivan (2004), Emily (2005), Katrina (2005), Rita (2005), Wilma (2005), Dean (2007), and Felix (2007). The previous decades with the most Category 5 hurricanes were the 1930s and 1960s, with six occurring between 1930 and 1939 (before naming began). Nine Atlantic hurricanes—[[Hurricane Camille|Camille]], [[Hurricane Allen|Allen]], [[Hurricane Andrew|Andrew]], [[Hurricane Isabel|Isabel]], [[Hurricane Ivan|Ivan]], [[Hurricane Dean|Dean]], [[Hurricane Felix|Felix]], [[Hurricane Irma|Irma]] and [[Hurricane Maria|Maria]]—reached Category 5 intensity on more than one occasion; that is, by reaching Category 5 intensity, weakening to a Category 4 status or lower, and then becoming a Category 5 hurricane again. Such hurricanes have their dates shown together. Camille, Andrew, Dean, Felix, Irma, and Maria each attained Category 5 status twice during their lifespans. Allen, Isabel, and Ivan reached Category 5 intensity on three separate occasions. However, no Atlantic hurricane has reached Category 5 intensity more than three times during its lifespan. The [[1932 Cuba hurricane]] holds the record for the most time spent as a Category 5 hurricane (although it took place before satellite or aircraft reconnaissance, so this record may be somewhat suspect). Irma holds the record for the longest continuous span as a Category 5 storm in the satellite era.{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/1992andrew_add.html|title=Addendum Hurricane Andrew|last=Rappaport|first=Edward N.|work=National Hurricane Center|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration}} Thirty-three Category 5 hurricanes have been recorded in the [[Atlantic basin]] since 1851, when records began. Only one Category 5 has been recorded in July, eight in August, nineteen in September, five in October, and one in November. There have been no officially recorded June or off-season Category 5 hurricanes. The July and August Category 5 hurricanes reached their high intensities in both the [[Gulf of Mexico]] and the [[Caribbean Sea]]. These are the areas most favorable for tropical cyclone development in those months.{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pastprofile.shtml|title=Tropical Cyclone Climatology|author=Staff writer|first=|date=|year=2010|work=National Hurricane Center|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=November 30, 2010}} September sees the most Category 5 hurricanes. This coincides with the climatological peak of the Atlantic hurricane season, which occurs in early September.{{cite web|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/G1.html|title=Tropical Cyclone FAQ G1) When is hurricane season ?|last=Dorst|first=Neal|date=June 10, 2010|work=National Hurricane Center|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060718065833/http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/G1.html|archivedate=2006-07-18|deadurl=yes|accessdate=November 30, 2010|df=}} September Category 5s reached their strengths in any of the [[Gulf of Mexico]], [[Caribbean Sea]], and open Atlantic. These places are where September tropical cyclones are likely to form. Many of these hurricanes are either [[Cape Verde hurricane|Cape Verde-type storms]], which develop their strength by having a great deal of open water; or so-called Bahama busters, which intensify over the warm [[Loop Current]] in the Gulf of Mexico.{{cite web|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/A2.html|title=Tropical Cyclone FAQ A2) What is a "Cape Verde" hurricane?|last=Landsea|first=Christopher W.|date=2010-06-08|work=Hurricane Research Division — Atlantic Oceanographic and Meteorological Laboratory|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=November 30, 2010}} All six Category 5 hurricanes in October and November reached their intensities in the western Caribbean, a region that Atlantic hurricanes strongly gravitate toward late in the season. This is due to the climatology of the area, which sometimes has a high-altitude [[anticyclone]] that promotes rapid intensification late in the season, as well as warm waters. ==Systems== {| class="wikitable sortable" width="100%" ! scope="col" width="5%"|Name ! scope="col" width="15%" data-sort-type="isoDate"|Dates as a

{{Col-end}} ==Landfalls== [[File:Hurricane camille.jpg|thumb|200px|right|[[Hurricane Camille]], a landfalling Category 5 hurricane]] All Atlantic Category 5 hurricanes have made landfall at some location at hurricane strength. Most Category 5 hurricanes in the Atlantic make landfall because of their proximity to land in the Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico, where the usual synoptic weather patterns carry them towards land, as opposed to the westward, oceanic mean track of Eastern Pacific hurricanes.{{cite web|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/G8.html|title=Tropical Cyclone FAQ G8) Why do hurricanes hit the East coast of the U.S., but never the West coast?|author=Landsea, Christopher W|date=2010-06-08|work=Atlantic Oceanographic and Meteorological Laboratory|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|accessdate=2010-11-30}} Sixteen of the storms made landfall while at Category 5 intensity; 2007 and 2017 are the only years in which two storms made landfall at this intensity. Many of these systems made landfall shortly after weakening from a Category 5 hurricane. This weakening can be caused by dry air near land, shallower waters due to [[continental shelf|shelving]], interaction with land, or cooler waters near shore. In southern Florida, the return period for a Category 5 hurricane is roughly once every 50 years.{{cite journal|last=Landsea|first=Christopher W.|last2=Franklin |first2=James L. |last3=McAdie |first3=Colin J. |last4=Beven |first4=John L. |last5=Gross |first5=James M. |last6=Jarvinen |first6=Brian R. |last7=Pasch |first7=Richard J. |last8=Rappaport |first8=Edward N. |last9=Dunion |first9=Jason P. |last10=Dodge |first10=Peter P.|year=2004|title=A Reanalysis of Hurricane Andrew's Intensity|journal=Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society|volume=85|issue=11|page=1699|issn=0003-0007|doi=10.1175/BAMS-85-11-1699|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pdf/04landsea.pdf|accessdate=2010-11-30|bibcode = 2004BAMS...85.1699L }} The following table lists these hurricanes by [[landfall]] intensity. {{clear}}

[[Delaware]] has three state forests, one in each county, totaling more than {{convert|19000|acres|km2}}. These natural resource areas are managed by the [http://dda.delaware.gov/forestry/ Delaware Department of Agriculture Forest Service].
[http://dda.delaware.gov/forestry/forest.shtml see also Delaware State Forests]
==Blackbird State Forest== [[File:Blackbird pond.jpg|thumb |alt=Blackbird Pond "align"=right "border" alt text|Blackbird Pond is located on the Meadows Tract of Blackbird State Forest in New Castle County, Delaware]] Located north of [[Smyrna, Delaware|Smyrna]], [http://dda.delaware.gov/forestry/maps/2011_Maps/Blackbird.pdf '''Blackbird State Forest'''] covers approximately {{convert|5400|acre|km2}} on the border of [[New Castle County, Delaware|New Castle]]/[[Kent County, Delaware|Kent]] counties. The [http://dda.delaware.gov/forestry/maps.shtml ten tracts] of Blackbird State Forest are open to the public for nature walks, hiking, jogging, and horseback riding all year. It features a 1/2-mile, wheelchair-accessible wildlife and nature interpretation trail on the [http://dda.delaware.gov/forestry/maps/2009_Maps/2009_Blackbird/TyHRC_from_Dobson.pdf Tybout Tract] and the Blackbird Education Center on the [http://dda.delaware.gov/forestry/maps/2009_Maps/2009_Blackbird/meadows.pdf Meadows Tract]. Long-range management plans for Blackbird State Forest outline goals for timber production, wildlife habitat, recreation, soil and water protection, wetland and endangered species protection, and public education.
Many educational programs are available at the [http://dda.delaware.gov/forestry/educat.shtml Blackbird State Forest Education Center] on the Meadows Tract. Complementing a center at Redden State Forest, the facility has two meeting spaces and interactive displays: The Life Cycle of a Forest, Tree Identification, Invasive Species, Urban/Community Forestry, and Wildland Firefighting. Visitors can see a diorama of a beaver pond, a working beehive, and exotic and native insects. Work has also begun on a new nature trail, demonstration saw mill, and arboretum.
===History of Blackbird State Forest=== As a state forest, Blackbird began with the 1941 acquisition of the Tybout Tract, purchased for $6,916.20 when land prices in New Castle County presented a rare opportunity for the Forestry Department. 1941’s Annual Report of the Forestry Department stated: :“For many years there has been a marked public concern over the failure of the Department to acquire State Forest lands in New Castle County but with only income funds at the disposal of the Department for acquisition purposes it has been expedient to spend those funds where the greatest acreage could be acquired per dollar expended. However, with the offer of a block of land in lower New Castle County at a figure comparable to similar lands in Sussex County the handicap of price was removed and the department has succeeded in acquiring 672 acres. . . lying west of Blackbird in New Castle County.”
==Redden State Forest== [[File:Redden Center.JPG|thumb |alt=Redden Education Center "align"=right "border" alt text|The Redden Forest Education Center can be found on the Headquarters Tract of Redden State Forest in Sussex County, Delaware]][http://dda.delaware.gov/forestry/maps/2009_Maps/2009_Redden/REDDEN_overview.pdf '''Redden State Forest'''] contains 18 separate tracts covering over {{convert|12000|acre|km2}} in [[Sussex County, Delaware|Sussex County]] just north of [[Georgetown, Delaware|Georgetown]], the county seat. The modern Redden State Forest is the consolidation of several Sussex County forest tracts, including the Ellendale State Forest. The [[Ellendale State Forest Picnic Facility]] was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1991.<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> The first land was acquired in 1928, and since then the forest has continued to grow, with acquisitions as late as 2008. Popular activities at the forest include in-season hunting, horseback-riding, nature observation, and hiking.
Redden State Forest is also home to one of Delaware's two forest education centers. The [[Redden Forest Education Center]] includes exhibits on the history of forestry in Delaware, forest pests, urban forestry, and the importance of forests within watersheds.
===History of Redden State Forest=== [[File:Redden lodge.jpg|thumb |alt=Redden Lodge "align"=right "border" alt text|Redden Lodge was built around 1903 and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. It can be found on the Headquarters Tract of Redden State Forest in Sussex County, Delaware]] Much of Redden State Forest’s history is tied to the railroad. The Junction & Breakwater Railroad, one of Delaware’s earliest rail systems, was completed in 1868. A railroad station was established in 1870 near what would later become Redden State Forest. The station was originally known as Carey’s Station, but a short time later was renamed for Col. William O. Redden. Col. Redden played a prevalent role in Sussex County as he served in the Civil War, was sheriff of Sussex County from 1838–1840, a member of Delaware’s House of Representatives from 1840–1846, including Speaker of the House in 1843, and was instrumental in establishing a railroad system in Delaware.
In 1877 a {{convert|230|acre|km2|adj=on}} farm near the Redden Station and owned by William W. Donovan proceeded through Orphan’s Court following his death. This land is now a portion of Redden State Forest’s Headquarters Tract. Transcripts of the court proceedings mention a large, two-story dwelling with an attached single story, which fits the description of Redden State Forest’s Manager’s House (currently the Redden office).
Charles C. Stockley, the Governor of Delaware from 1872 to 1876, purchased the Donovan Farm in 1879. In 1901 Frank Thompson purchased {{convert|844|acre|km2}} of land including the original {{convert|230|acre|km2|adj=on}} Donovan Farm. Mr. Thompson was the son of the president of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company. In 1903 the club house (Redden Lodge) appeared on Sussex County tax records. From 1903 to 1919 the Lodge was used by Pennsylvania Railroad Company officials and guests for hunting (primarily quail, since much of the surrounding area at that time was fields and hedgerows). Visitors arrived at the Redden Station by train from Philadelphia and proceeded to the Lodge by horse and buggy. The carriages and horses were kept in the Horse Barn, which is now the Redden Education Center.
In 1936 under the leadership of Delaware’s first State Forester, William S. Taber, the State Forestry Department purchased the {{convert|844|acre|km2}} that is now the Headquarters Tract from Richard Houghton, who had acquired the property following its use by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company. Since that time, the Headquarters Tract has grown to over {{convert|1800|acre|km2}}. On July 4, 1970, lightning struck the Lodge, and the resulting fire burned the entire west wing and kitchen. The burned section was rebuilt in 1976. In 1990 the Lodge, Manager’s House, and Horse Barn were placed on the National Register of Historic Places.
The Delaware Forest Service acquired funding from the Delaware General Assembly and, working with the Delaware Department of Administrative Services, Division of Facilities Management, renovated these historic structures. The Redden Lodge was rededicated in 1996, the Manager’s House opened as the Redden office in 1998, and the Horse Barn opened in 2000 as the Education Center. These three structures are now the centerpiece of Redden State Forest.
==Taber State Forest== [http://dda.delaware.gov/forestry/maps/051612_Taber.pdf '''Taber State Forest'''] covers over {{convert|1200|acre|km2}} in [[Kent County, Delaware|Kent County]] and is located {{convert|10|mi|km}} southwest of [[Harrington, Delaware|Harrington]]. Parker Road south off of [[Delaware Route 14]], and the Maryland state line generally form the western boundary. About {{convert|17|acre|m2}} actually extends westward into the state of Maryland. Burrsville Road running southeast from Parker Road cuts through near the center of the land holdings. Saulsbury Creek Road generally forms a boundary for the southwest extent of the property.
Taber State Forest is a primitive use facility and there is no formal office onsite. It is primarily used for hunting, hiking, and wildlife habitat. In addition, the forest is also managed for timber production.
===History of Taber State Forest=== Although officially dedicated in 1994, the origin of Taber State Forest was 1984, when the Delaware Forest Service received the {{convert|350|acre|km2|adj=on}} Saulsbury Farm. Also included at Taber State Forest is the building known as the Smith School House (now a residence on the property). The Cooper and Cooper Study (found in the holdings of the Delaware Division of Historical and Cultural Affairs) describes the Smith School as a one-teacher schoolhouse with an average student population of 23. The school operated 180 days of the year.
Saulsbury Farm Gravesite: The Saulsbury Tract is home of the Saulsbury family burial grave, which contains a memorial to [[Gove Saulsbury]], the 41st governor of Delaware (1865–1871). This historic gravesite is approximately {{convert|50|ft|m|abbr=on}}. by {{convert|75|ft|m|abbr=on}}. with 16 graves. The site has one large group monument and three small grave stones with a two-rail split rail fence around the site. Deed restrictions state this parcel must remain as a burial site and be maintained as such.

page.title: List of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2017

revision.comment: The referenced article for this entry was written in Bismarck but the incident happened in Bowman County ND. The Little Missouri is no where near Bismarck
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Use American English|date=May 2016}} The following is a '''list of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2017'''. It is one of several [[list of pipeline accidents in the United States|lists of U.S. pipeline accidents]]. See also [[list of natural gas and oil production accidents in the United States]]. {{expand list|date=April 2013}} __NOTOC__ <!--begin temporary compact toc--> <!-- something nicer-looking and more navigable should be done here; this is a temporary TOC to ease navigation --> <!-- | bgcolor=#dddddd align=center colspan=11 | See also – [[#References|References]] --> <!--end compact toc-->
== Incidents ==
This is not a complete list of all pipeline accidents. '''For natural gas alone''', the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA), a United States Department of Transportation agency, has collected data on more than 3,200 accidents deemed serious or significant since 1987.
A "significant incident" results in any of the following consequences: * fatality or injury requiring in-patient hospitalization * $50,000 or more in total costs, measured in 1984 dollars * liquid releases of five or more barrels (42 US gal/barrel) * releases resulting in an unintentional fire or explosion
PHMSA and the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) post incident data and results of investigations into accidents involving pipelines that carry a variety of products, including natural gas, oil, diesel fuel, gasoline, kerosene, jet fuel, carbon dioxide, and other substances. Occasionally pipelines are repurposed to carry different products.<ref>Data sets of PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents for 1986-2001, 2002-2009, and 2010-2017 can be downloaded from the tab by that name on the PHMSA's Pipeline Incident Flagged Files page at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/data-and-statistics/pipeline/pipeline-incident-flagged-files, accessed 2018.01.10. PHMSA Corrective Action Orders are at https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/CAO_opid_0.html. PHMSA Pipeline Failure Investigation Reports are at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/safety-reports/pipeline-failure-investigation-reports. NTSB Pipeline Accident Reports are at https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/pipeline.aspx.</ref>
* On January 7, a [[Colonial Pipeline]] stubline leaked gasoline into Shoal Creek, in [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/breakingnews/story/2017/jan/07/local-haz-mat-teams-contain-gasoline-leak-near-tennessee-river/406330/ |title=Colonial Pipeline leaks in Chattanooga near Tennessee River |publisher=Times Free Press |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170108134928/http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/breakingnews/story/2017/jan/07/local-haz-mat-teams-contain-gasoline-leak-near-tennessee-river/406330/ |archivedate=January 8, 2017 }}</ref> * On January 14, the Ozark Pipeline, an [[Enbridge]], now Marathon, division, spilled about 18,900 gallons of light oil, at the Lawrence Pump Station, near [[Halltown, Missouri]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lawrencecountyrecord.com/news/article_517163be-31bf-11e7-8caf-53a312062bf1.html|title=Enbridge reps discuss oil spill cleanup, restoration|publisher=}}</ref> * On January 16, a gas pipeline exploded and burned, near [[Spearman, Texas]]. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/texas/article/Reports-Texas-Panhandle-gas-explosion-captured-10872641.php |title=Reports: Texas Panhandle gas explosion captured by police dashcam |publisher= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170126071038/http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/texas/article/Reports-Texas-Panhandle-gas-explosion-captured-10872641.php |archivedate=January 26, 2017 }}</ref> * On January 19, a [[Tallgrass Energy Partners|Tallgrass]] Pony Express Pipeline failed in [[Logan County, Colorado]], spilling about 420,300 gallons of crude oil. The cause of the failure was unknown.<ref name="auto7">{{cite web|url=http://kfgo.com/news/articles/2017/nov/18/top-20-onshore-us-petroleum-spills-since-2010/|title=Top 20 onshore US petroleum spills since 2010|first=Midwest Communications|last=Inc.|website=The Mighty 790 KFGO}}</ref> * On January 25, a [[Magellan Midstream Partners|Magellan]] pipeline leaked 46,830 gallons (1,115 barrels) of diesel fuel onto private agricultural land, in Worth County, Iowa, near [[Hanlontown, Iowa|Hanlontown]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/2017/01/25/pipeline-leaks-thousands-gallons-diesel-northern-iowa/97051728/|title=Pipeline Leaks 138,600 Gallons of Diesel in Northern Iowa|publisher=The Des Moines Register}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://globegazette.com/news/local/worth-county-agencies-reimbursed-for-january-diesel-spill-costs/article_1896bde5-38ba-56dd-83ba-f120f6747e95.html|title=Worth County agencies reimbursed for January diesel spill costs|first=COURTNEY FIORINI|last=courtney.fiorini@globegazette.com|publisher=}}</ref> * On January 30, a Texas Department of Transportation crew dug into the 30-inch-diameter [[Seaway Pipeline]], near [[Blue Ridge, Texas]], spraying crude oil across road. About 210,000 gallons of crude were spilled. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kxii.com/content/news/BREAKING-Ruptured-pipeline-near-Blue-Ridge-spews-oil--412209343.html |title=Blue Ridge pipeline spill affecting flow of oil nationally |first=Brittany |last=Harlow |publisher= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170201054041/http://www.kxii.com/content/news/BREAKING-Ruptured-pipeline-near-Blue-Ridge-spews-oil--412209343.html |archivedate=February 1, 2017 }}</ref><ref name="dot.gov">{{cite web|url=https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_30829.html?nocache=9093#_Incidents_tab_4|title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications - Operator Information|website=primis.phmsa.dot.gov}}</ref> * On January 31, a DCP pipeline exploded under a runway, at Panola County Airport-Sharpe Field in [[Texas]]. There were no injuries, but the airport shut that runway down for an extended amount of time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.news-journal.com/news/2017/feb/01/flights-canceled-panola-county-airport-after-pipel/ |title=Flights canceled at Panola County airport after pipeline explosion - Longview News-Journal |publisher= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170203001840/https://www.news-journal.com/news/2017/feb/01/flights-canceled-panola-county-airport-after-pipel/ |archivedate=February 3, 2017 }}</ref> * On February 9, a [[Phillips 66]] [[natural gas liquids]] pipeline (TENDS pipeline Sorrento system)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ogj.com/articles/print/volume-95/issue-17/in-this-issue/transportation/texaco-plans-louisiana-ngl-system-expansion.html |title=Texaco plans Louisiana NGL system expansion |date=1997-04-28 |publisher=Oil and Gas Journal |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211084342/http://www.ogj.com/articles/print/volume-95/issue-17/in-this-issue/transportation/texaco-plans-louisiana-ngl-system-expansion.html |archivedate=February 11, 2017 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160825006415/en/Phillips-66-Partners-Acquire-South-Louisiana-NGL |title=Phillips 66 Partners to Acquire South Louisiana NGL Logistics Assets |date=August 25, 2016 |publisher=BusinessWire |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211155227/http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160825006415/en/Phillips-66-Partners-Acquire-South-Louisiana-NGL |archivedate=February 11, 2017 }}</ref> near the Williams-Discovery natural gas plant on [[US Route 90]] near [[Paradis, Louisiana]] exploded while being cleaned, killing one worker, and sending another worker to a burn unit. Traffic on US 90 and La 631 was shut down and residents in the area evacuated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wgno.com/2017/02/09/fire-reported-at-natural-gas-plant-in-paradis/ |title=One missing, two injured in Paradis pipeline explosion |date=February 9, 2017 |author=Heather Miller |publisher=WGNO |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170210050541/http://wgno.com/2017/02/09/fire-reported-at-natural-gas-plant-in-paradis/ |archivedate=February 10, 2017 }} The pipeline can be traced with the [http://www.phillips66pipeline.com/maps/ Phillips 66 pipeline finder] and viewed via [https://www.google.com/maps/place/LA-631+%26+W+Bayou+Rd,+Des+Allemands,+LA+70030/@29.8621692,-90.4479067,93m/data=!3m1!1e3!8m2!3d29.8710889!4d-90.4495833 satellite map]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.houmatoday.com/news/20170216/pipeline-explosion-still-being-investigated |title=Pipeline explosion still being investigated |first=Bridget Mire S Staff |last=Writer |publisher= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170217042043/http://www.houmatoday.com/news/20170216/pipeline-explosion-still-being-investigated |archivedate=February 17, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.osha.gov/pls/imis/establishment.inspection_detail?id=1210046.015|title=Inspection Detail - Occupational Safety and Health Administration|website=www.osha.gov}}</ref> * On February 15, 2017, a 36-inch-diameter [[Kinder Morgan]] natural gas pipeline exploded and burned in [[Refugio County, Texas]]. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.victoriaadvocate.com/news/2017/feb/15/nature-gas-pipeline-explosion-rocks-crossroads/ |title=Natural gas pipeline explosion rocks Crossroads - Victoria Advocate |publisher= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170216072950/https://www.victoriaadvocate.com/news/2017/feb/15/nature-gas-pipeline-explosion-rocks-crossroads/ |archivedate=February 16, 2017 }}</ref> The flames were visible 50 miles away. Refugio County Chief Deputy Sheriff Gary Wright said the explosion occurred at an apparent weak point in the pipeline that must have required maintenance, but KM disputed the issue.<ref>Jordan Blum, “Investigation into Kinder Morgan pipeline explosion is underway,” ''Houston Chronicle'', February 15, 2017.</ref> Residents as far as 60 miles away thought it was an earthquake, while others described it as "a thunder roll that wouldn’t end.”<ref>Reuters staff, "Kinder Morgan gas pipeline explodes in Texas, no injuries," Reuters, February 15, 2017, https://www.reuters.com/article/us-pipeline-fire-kindermorgan-texas/kinder-morgan-gas-pipeline-explodes-in-texas-no-injuries-idUSKBN15U1SS, accessed 2018.01.07.</ref> According to the PHMSA incident listing, "the incident was most likely caused by some combination of stress factors on the pipeline." The explosion and resulting fire cost $525,197 in property damage. The pipe was installed in 1964.<ref name="primis">Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration operator data, http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170603005753/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/ |date=June 3, 2017 }}, Retrieved April 1, 2016.</ref> * On February 27, a crude oil pipeline ruptured in [[Falls City, Texas]], spilling about 42,630 gallons of crude oil. The cause was from internal corrosion.<ref name="dot.gov"/> * On March 29, a natural-gas leak of a high-pressure pipeline, in [[Providence, Rhode Island]], owned by [[Spectra Energy]], released about 19 million cubic feet of natural gas, or enough natural gas to heat and keep the lights on for 190,000 homes for a single day. Approximately two gallons of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) were also released, in the form of contaminated natural gas condensate.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ecori.org/renewable-energy/2017/5/4/gas-leak-emissions-revealed |title=Leaked Natural Gas was Enough to Heat 190,000 Homes |publisher= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170505183955/https://www.ecori.org/renewable-energy/2017/5/4/gas-leak-emissions-revealed |archivedate=May 5, 2017 }}</ref> * On April 4, a pump on the [[Dakota Access Pipeline]] spilled about 84 gallons of oil, at a pump station in [[Tulare, South Dakota|Tulare]], [[South Dakota]]. The leak was not noticed until May 9.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2017/05/11/Dakota-Access-pipeline-leaks-84-gallons-in-South-Dakota/9791494505216/ |title=Dakota Access pipeline leaks 84 gallons in South Dakota |publisher= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170511161414/http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2017/05/11/Dakota-Access-pipeline-leaks-84-gallons-in-South-Dakota/9791494505216/ |archivedate=May 11, 2017 }}</ref> * On April 13 and 14, it was discovered that [[Energy Transfer Partners]] spilled drilling fluid into two separate wetlands in rural Ohio while constructing the Rover Pipeline. The spills occurred in wetlands near [[Richland County, Ohio]]. The spill on the 13th released 2 million gallons of drilling fluid and the spill on the 14th released approximately 50,000 gallons of drilling fluid.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Norris |first1=Courtney |title=The Rover Pipeline leaked millions of gallons of drilling fluid into Ohio wetlands |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/two-weeks-rover-pipeline-leaked-drilling-fluid-ohio-wetlands/ |website=PBS Newshour |accessdate=8 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170604023054/http://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/two-weeks-rover-pipeline-leaked-drilling-fluid-ohio-wetlands/ |archivedate=June 4, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Geiling|first1=Natasha|title=Company behind Dakota Access Pipeline spills over 2 million gallons of drilling fluids into Ohio wetlands|url=https://thinkprogress.org/dakota-access-company-ohio-spill-d73cb24c8dd6|website=ThinkProgress|accessdate=8 June 2017}}</ref> * On April 21, a [[Plains All American Pipeline]], experienced a crude oil release on the Buffalo Pipeline, near [[Loyal, Oklahoma]]. About 19,000 gallons of crude oil were spilled.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecowatch.com/buffalo-pipeline-leak-oklahoma-2377971688.html |title=Buffalo Pipeline Leaks 19,000 Gallons of Crude Oil on Farmland in Oklahoma |date=April 25, 2017 |publisher= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170507024029/http://www.ecowatch.com/buffalo-pipeline-leak-oklahoma-2377971688.html |archivedate=May 7, 2017 }}</ref> * On April 22, a 1,050-gallon oil pipeline spill in [[Bowman County, North Dakota]] polluted a tributary of the Little Missouri River, but was prevented from flowing into the larger waterway.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nicholson|first1=Blake|title=Oil Pipeline Spill Pollutes North Dakota Tributary|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/north-dakota/articles/2017-04-25/bowman-county-pipeline-spills-1-050k-of-oil-and-saltwater|website=USNews|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=6 May 2017}}</ref> * On May 8, a Wood River Pipelines (part of [[Koch Industries]]) line broke in [[Warrensburg, Illinois]], spill 250 gallons of crude oil.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.illinoishomepage.net/news/local-news/pipeline-spill-controlled/710455965|title=Pipeline Spill Controlled|first=Kaitlyn Connolly, Richard|last=Flesch|date=May 12, 2017|publisher=}}</ref> * On May 25, workers were installing a replacement pipeline at a tank battery, near [[Mead, Colorado]], when there was an explosion and fire. One worker was killed, and, 3 others injured.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://denver.cbslocal.com/2017/08/11/oil-tank-explosion-mead-anadarko/|title=Deadly Oil Tank Explosion Caused By Pipe Installment|date=August 11, 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://denver.cbslocal.com/2017/05/26/mead-oil-tank-battery-explosion-fire/|title=Residents Shaken By Oil Tank Explosion|date=May 26, 2017|publisher=}}</ref> * On July 13, a contractor doing maintenance on Magellan's Longhorn Pipeline hit that pipeline, in [[Bastrop County, Texas]]. About 87,000 gallons of crude oil were spilled, resulting in evacuations of nearby residents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fox7austin.com/news/local-news/267668049-story|title=Evacuations in Bastrop County after crude oil leak|first=|last=FOX|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.statesman.com/news/local/new-data-shows-bastrop-county-oil-spill-leaked-000-gallons/Y8YK4xM4uPE37actcJi1HP/|title=New data shows Bastrop County oil spill leaked 87,000 gallons|publisher=}}</ref> * On July 27, while installing a water pipeline by horizontal drilling, a contractor hit a ONEOK Natural Gas Liquids pipeline, spilling about 126,000 gallons of NGL's, near [[Watford City, North Dakota]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bismarcktribune.com/business/local/contractor-that-damaged-pipeline-is-repeat-offender/article_7e83cb2b-9429-5ed5-872f-73940b86f15b.html|title=Contractor that damaged pipeline is repeat offender|first=AMY DALRYMPLE Bismarck|last=Tribune|publisher=}}</ref> * On August 2, a pipeline leaked up to 1,000 gallons of oil, in [[Signal Hill, California]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstelegram.com/general-news/20170802/oil-pipeline-spill-shuts-signal-hill-streets|title=Oil pipeline spill shuts Signal Hill streets|date=August 2, 2017|publisher=}}</ref> * On August 2, a contractor ruptured a jet fuel pipeline, in [[Parkland, Washington]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/news/local/article165087782.html|title=Jet fuel pipeline punctured in Parkland|publisher=}}</ref> * On August 2, 2017, a natural gas explosion and fire struck the [[Minnehaha Academy]] in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]]. Workers may have been moving a gas meter when the explosion hit, killing two people and injuring at least nine others, according to investigators.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://patch.com/minnesota/southwestminneapolis/minnehaha-academy-blast-investigation-could-take-year-ntsb|title=Minnehaha Academy Blast Investigation Could Take A Year: NTSB|date=August 5, 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>NTSB accident file preliminary report DCA17MP007, https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/DCA17MP007-prelim-report.pdf</ref> * On September 22, a gas pipeline exploded and burned in [[Welda, Kansas]]. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fox4kc.com/2017/09/22/pipeline-explodes-southwest-of-the-metro-sending-flames-shooting-into-the-air/|title=Pipeline explodes southwest of the metro, sending flames shooting into the air|date=September 22, 2017|publisher=}}</ref> * On September 22, fire broke out at a substation of the [[Iroquois Pipeline]], causing homes to be evacuated and about two miles of Route 37 to be shut down for several hours, near [[Waddington, New York]]. The cause of the failure was never found.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.watertowndailytimes.com/news05/friday-pipeline-fire-results-in-evacuations-road-closures-20170926|title=Friday pipeline fire results in evacuations, road closures|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_8310.html?nocache=8621#_Incidents_tab_3|title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications - Operator Information|website=primis.phmsa.dot.gov}}</ref> * On October 18, Louisiana-based oil company LLOG Exploration had a crude oil spill of about 672,000 gallons, 40 miles southeast of [[Venice, Louisiana]], citing the cause as a cracked pipeline under the [[Gulf of Mexico]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://simmonsvoice.com/2017/10/25/louisiana-oil-spill-is-largest-since-2010/|title=Louisiana oil spill is largest since 2010|date=October 25, 2017|publisher=}}</ref> * On October 23, 2017, at a facility owned by EDC-Timken, operated and maintained by [[Columbia Gas Transmission]] in [[Navarre, Ohio]], an unintended natural gas release was noted by the onsite company personnel. While investigating the sound, the single bolt hinged closure, that appeared to be the source of the release, failed. The closure failure fatally injured one technician. The equipment was installed in 1989.<ref name="primis"/> The leak just south of [[Canton, Ohio]], forced authorities to evacuate a neighborhood.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/ohio/articles/2017-10-23/man-working-on-natural-gas-pipeline-killed-in-northeast-ohio |title= Gas Pipeline Explosion Kills Man Doing Maintenance Work|date=October 23, 2017 |website=usnews.com |publisher= US News}}</ref> * On November 16, the [[Keystone Pipeline]] leaked about 408,500 gallons of crude oil, near [[Amherst, South Dakota]]. The pipeline was shut down within 15 minutes of the leak's discovery. Later, the NTSB found a metal tracked vehicle had run over this section of pipeline, causing the damage.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/16/us/keystone-pipeline-leaks-south-dakota.html|title=Keystone Pipeline Leaks 210,000 Gallons of Oil in South Dakota|first1=Mitch|last1=Smith|first2=Julie|last2=Bosman|date=November 16, 2017|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> During cleanup activities, state officials say a semi-trailer driver hauling hazardous material to and from the Keystone oil pipeline leak site purposely dumped soil contaminated with crude oil on the side of a northeastern South Dakota road.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kfgo.com/news/articles/2018/jan/14/semi-driver-suspected-of-dumping-contaminated-soil-from-pipeline-leak/|title=Semi driver suspected of dumping contaminated soil from pipeline leak|first=Midwest Communications|last=Inc.|website=The Mighty 790 KFGO}}</ref> The original estimate was doubled to {{convert|9600|oilbbl|usgal}} in April 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-transcanada-pipeline-leak/keystone-pipeline-leak-in-south-dakota-about-double-previous-estimate-paper-idUSKBN1HE0T7|title=Keystone pipeline leak in South Dakota about double previous...|first=Reuters|last=Editorial|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/PAB1801.pdf |title=Accident report |website=www.ntsb.gov |format=PDF}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_32334.html?nocache=5134#_Incidents_tab_3|title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications - Operator Information|website=primis.phmsa.dot.gov}}</ref> * On November 16, three men were injured in a gas pipeline fire in northeastern [[Weld County, Colorado]]. One later died of his injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.greeleytribune.com/news/local/three-injured-in-oil-gas-well-fire-near-galeton/|title=One DCP employee, two contractors, injured in gas pipeline fire near Galeton|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2017/11/22/greeley-oil-company-worker-dies/|title=Man dies of injuries suffered in gas pipeline fire east of Greeley; two other workers still being treated|date=November 22, 2017|publisher=}}</ref> * On November 20, 2017, [[Kinder Morgan]]’s Connecticut Expansion Project's pipeline test at the [[Agawam, Massachusetts]] compressor station discharged 16,500 gallons of hazardous wastewater onto the soil of the compressor station yard; the wastewater contained heavy metals, lead, and carcinogens such as tetrachloroethylene and phthalate. Kinder Morgan blamed subcontractor Henkels & McCoy for an operator error.<ref name="auto9">Heather Bellow, "Senators renew pipeline worries," ''Berkshire Eagle'', January 4, 2018, p. A1.</ref> * On November 20, a [[Consumers Energy]] 22-inch-diameter gas transmission pipeline carrying gas at 600 psi exploded and burned, in [[Orion Township, Michigan]], knocking out the county 911 system, and causing some evacuations. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/local/oakland-county/2017/11/20/fire-blaze-auburn-hills-orion-township/107894444/|title=Oakland explosion: ‘Loss of pressure,’ then big blast|publisher=}}</ref> * On November 29, 2017, in [[Richmond, Massachusetts]], a [[Kinder Morgan]] pipeline overpressure triggered a relief valve to open, releasing natural gas for a blowdown that lasted 40 minutes and sounded like a jet engine. The gas escaped into a nearby residential neighborhood. Firefighters responded to the leak and closed the road. When contacted, pipeline personnel had no idea that there was a problem, and offered no reason for their equipment malfunction.<ref>Heather Bellow, "Release of gas in pipeline 'unusual'," ''Berkshire Eagle'', December 28, 2017, pp. A1, A3.</ref> * On December 5, a father and his adult son were killed when a stuck tractor they were trying to free ruptured and ignited a 20-inch-diameter gas pipeline in [[Lee County, Illinois]]. Two others were seriously injured.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wral.com/two-killed-two-seriously-injured-in-lee-county-pipeline-explosion/17165866/|title=Two killed, two seriously injured in Lee County pipeline explosion :: WRAL.com|first=|last=WRAL|publisher=}}</ref> The explosion was on [[Kinder Morgan]]’s [[Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America]], a 9,200-mile long system that transports natural gas from Texas and Louisiana to Chicago; Kinder Morgan issued a force majeure notice on the pipeline indicating a “third-party strike” as the reason for taking part of the Illinois Lateral out of service.<ref>Paul Ausick, "Kinder Morgan Illinois Pipeline Explodes, Kills 2," 24/7 Wall St, Dec. 6, 2017, http://247wallst.com/energy-business/2017/12/06/kinder-morgan-illinois-pipeline-explodes-kills-2/, accessed 2018.01.07.</ref> * On December 6, a gas pipeline exploded and burned, in [[Eddy County, New Mexico]]. Residents within 2 miles of the site were evacuated, and, several roads in the area were closed. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.currentargus.com/story/news/local/2017/12/06/homes-evacuated-after-pipeline-explosion-near-loving/926135001/|title=Homes evacuated after suspected pipeline explosion near Loving|publisher=}}</ref> * On December 13, an [[Energy Transfer Partners]] gas pipeline exploded and burned, in [[Burleson County, Texas]]. There were no injuries reported.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://kxan.com/2017/12/13/watch-gas-explosion-in-burleson-county-could-be-seen-for-12-miles/|title=TOWER OF FLAMES: Pipeline explosion in Burleson County|date=December 13, 2017|publisher=}}</ref> * On December 31, 4 workers were injured, while working on a 10-inch gas main, in [[Boston, Massachusetts]], when the gas ignited. Gas had to burn a number of hours, due to cold conditions prevented shutting down gas in the area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://boston.cbslocal.com/2017/12/31/3-workers-injured-boston-gas-main-fire/|title=Homes Evacuated After Gas Main Fire; Workers Injured|date=December 31, 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}} {{List of pipeline accidents in the United States|state=autocollapse}} [[Category:Lists of pipeline accidents in the United States]]
